¶ This Carpenter / out of his slomber sterte
And herde oon cryen water / as he were wood
And thoghte allas / now cometh Nowelys flood
He sette hym vp / withoute wordes mo
And with his Ax / he smoot the corde atwo
And down gooth al / he foond neither to selle
Ne breed ne ale / til he cam to the Celle
Bred ne allebut shortli doun he felle .
Vpon the floor / and ther aswowne he lay
¶ Vp stirte hir / Alison and Nicholay
And cryden out and harrow / in the Strete
The neghebores / bothe smale and grete
In ronnen / for to gauren on this man
That aswowne lay / bothe pale and wan
For with the fal / he brosten hadde his arm
But stonde he moste / vnto his owene harm
For whan he spak / he was anon bore doun
With hende Nicholas and Alisoun
They tolden euery man / that he was wood
He was agast so / of Nowelys flood
Thurgh fantasie / that of his vanytee
He hadde yboght hym / knedyng tubbes thre
And hadde hem hanged / in the roof aboue
And that he preyde hem / for goddes loue
To sitten in the roof / par compaignye
¶ The folk gan laughen / at his fantasye
Into the roof / they kiken and they cape
And turned al his harm / vnto a Iape
For whatso / that this Carpenter answerde
It was for noght no man his reson herde
With othes grete / he was so sworn adoun
He was anon right boren doun
That he was holden wood / in al the toun
For euery clerk / anon right heeld with oother
They seyde / the man was wood / my leeue brother
And euery wight gan laughen at this stryf
Thus swyued / was the Carpenters wyf
For al his kepyng and his Ialousye
And Absolon / hath kist hir nether Iye
And Nicholas / is scalded in the toute
This tale is doon / and god saue al the route
¶ Here is ended / the Millerys tale ~
¶ The Prologe / of the Reues tale
Whan folk hadde laughen / at this nyce cas
Of Absolon / and hende Nicholas
Diuerse folk / diuersely they seyde
But for the moore part they lowe and pleyde
Ne at his tale / I seigh no man hym greue
But it were oonly / Osewold the Reue
By cause he was / of Carpenters craft
A litel Ire / is in his herte ylaft
He gan to grucche / and blamed it alite
So the ik quod he / ful wel koude I thee quyte
With bleryng of a proud Millerys Iye
If that me liste / speke of ribaudye
But ik am oold / me list no pleye for age
Gras tyme is doon / my fodder is now forage
This white top / writeth myne olde yerys
Myn herte / is also mowled / as myne herys
But if ik fare / as dooth an Openers
That ilke fruyt is euer lenger the wers
Til it be roten / in Mollok or in stree
We olde men / I drede so fare we
Til we be roten / kan we noght be rype
We hoppe alwey / whil that the world wol pipe
For in oure wil / ther stiketh euere a nayl
To haue an hoor heer / and a grene tayl
As hath a leek / for thogh oure myght be goon
Oure wil desireth folie / euere in oon
For whan we may noght doon / than wol we speke
Yet in oure asshen olde / is fyr yreke
Foure gleedes haue we / whiche I shal deuyse
Auauntyng lyyng Anger Coueitise
Thise foure sparkles / longen vnto eelde
Oure lymes / mowe wel been vnweelde
But wil ne shal noght faillen / that is sooth
And yet I haue alwey / a coltes tooth
As many a yeer / as it is passed henne
Syn that my tappe of lyf / bigan to renne
For sikerlik whan ik was bore anon
Deeth drogh the tappe of lyf / and leet it goon
And euere sith / hath so the tappe yronne
Til that almoost / al empty is the tonne
The streem of lyf / now droppeth on the chymbe
The sely tonge / may wel rynge and chymbe
Of wrecchednesse / that passed is ful yoore
With olde folk / saue dotage is namoore
¶ Whan that oure hoost hadde herd this sermonyng
He gan to speke / as lordly as a kyng
He seyde / what amounteth al this wit
What shal we speke alday / of holy writ
The deuel made / a Reue for to preche
Or of a Soutere / a Shipman / or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie noght the tyme
Lo Depeford / and it is half wey pryme
Lo Grenewych / ther many a sherewe is Inne
It were al tyme / thy tale to bigynne
¶ Now sires / quod this Osewold the Reue
I pray yow alle / that ye noght yow greue
Thogh I answere / and som del sette his howue
For leueful is / with force / force of showue
This dronken Millere / hath ytoold vs heer
How that / bigiled was a Carpenter
Parauenture in scorn / for I am oon
And by youre leue / I shal hym quyte anon
Right / in his cherles termes / wol I speke
I pray to god / his nekke mote to breke
He kan wel / in myn eye / seen a stalke
But in his owene / he kan noght seen a balke
Here endeth the Reuys prolog
Narrat
¶ Heere bigynneth / the Reues tale ~
AT Trompyngtoun nat fer fro Cantebrygge
Ther gooth a brook and ouer that a brygge
Vp on the which brook ther stant a Melle
And this is verray sooth that I yow telle
A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
As any pecok he was proud and gay
pipen he koude and fisshe and nettes beete
And torne coppes and wel wrastle and sheete
And by his belt he baar a long panade
And of a swerd ful trenchaunt was the blade
A ioly popper baar he in his pouche
Ther was no man for peril dorste hym touche
A sheffeld thwitel baar he in his hose
Round was his face and camuse was his nose
As piled as an Ape was his skulle
He was a Market beter at the fulle
Ther dorste no wight hand vp on hym legge
That he ne swoor he sholde anon abegge
A theef he was for sothe of corn and mele
And that a sleigh and vsant for to stele
His name was hoten deynous Symkyn
A wif he hadde comen of noble kyn
The person of the toun hir fader was
With hir he yaf ful many a panne a bras
For that Symkyn sholde in his blood allye
She was yfostred in a Nonnerye
For Symkyn wolde no wyf as he sayde
But she were wel ynorissed and a mayde
To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
And she was proud and peert as is a pye
A ful fair sighte was it vp on hem two
On halidayes biforn hir wolde he go
With his tipet wounden aboute his heed
And she cam after in a gyte of reed
And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
Ther dorste no wight clepen hire but dame
Was noon so hardy that wente by the weye
That with hire dorste rage or ones pleye
But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
With panade or with knyf or boydekyn
For Ialous folk been perilouse eueremo
Algate they wolde hir wyues wenden so
And eek for she was som del smoterlich
She was as digne as water in a dich
And ful of hoker and of bismare
Hir thoghte that a lady sholde hir spare
What for hir kynrede and hir nortelrye
That she hadde lerned in the Nonnerye
A doghter hadde they bitwix hem two
Of twenty yeer with outen any mo
Sauyng a child that was of hal yeer age
In Cradel it lay and was a propre page
This wenche thikke and wel ygrowen was
With camuse nose and eyen greye as glas
With buttokes brode and brestes rounde and hye
But right fair was hir heer I wol nat lye
The person of the toun for she was so feir
In purpos was to maken hir his heir
Bothe of his catel and his Mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpos was to makyn hir his eire
His purpos was for to bistowe hir hye
In to som worthy blood of Auncetrye
For holicherches good moot been despended
On holicherches blood that is descended
Ther fore he wolde his holy blood honoure
Thogh that he holy chirche sholde deuoure
Greet sokne hath this Miller out of doute
With whete and malt of al the land aboute
And nameliche ther was a greet Collegge
Men clepeth the soler halle at Cantebregge
Ther was hir whete and eek hir malt ygrounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Syk was this maunciple on a maladie
Men wenden wisly that he sholde dye
For which this Millere stal bothe mele and corn
An hondred tyme moore than biforn
For ther biforn he stal but curteisly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For which the wardeyn chidde and made fare
But ther of sette the Millere noght a tare
He craked boost and swoor it was noght so
Thanne were ther yonge poure scolers two
That dwelten in the halle of which I seye
Testyf they were and lusty for to pleye
And oonly for hir myrthe and reuerye
Vp on the wardeyn bisily they crye
To yeue hem leue but a litel stounde
To go to Mille and seen hir corn ygrounde
And hardily they dorste leye hir nekke
The Millere sholde noght stelen hem half a pekke
Of corn by sleighte ne by force hem reue
And at the laste the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn highte that oon and Aleyn highte that oother
Of oon town were they born that highte Strother
Fer in the North I kan noght telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy al his gere
They makyn redy al hir owen gere
And on an hors the sak he caste anon
Forth gooth Aleyn the clerk. and also Iohn
With good swerd and with bokeler by his syde
Iohn knew the wey hym neded no gyde
And at the Mille the sak adoun he layth
Aleyn spak first alhayl Symkyn in fayth
How fares thy faire doghter and thy wyf
Aleyn wel come quod Symkyn by my lyf
And Iohn also how now what do ye here
By god quod Iohn . Symond nede has na peere
Hym bihoues serue hym self that has na swayn
Or ellis he is a fool as clerkes sayn
Oure maunciple I hope he wol be deed
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his heed
And ther fore is I come and eek Alayn
To grynde oure corn and carie it heem agayn
I pray yow speed vs heythen what ye may
It shal be doon quod Symkyn by my fay
What wol ye doon whil that it is in hande
By god right by the hoper wol I stande
Quod Iohn and se how the corn gas In
Yet saw I neuere by my fader kyn
How that the hoper wagges til and fra
Aleyn answerde Iohn wiltow swa
Thanne wol I be byneth by my crown
And se how that the mele falles down
In to the trogh that sal be my desport
For Iohn in faith I may been of youre sort
I is as ille a Millere as ar ye
This Millere smyled of hir nycetee
And thoghte al this nys doon but for a wyle
They wene that no man may hem bigile
But by my thrift yet shal I blere hir Iye
For al the sleighte in hir phislophye
The moore queynte crekys that they make
The moore wol I stele whan I take
In stede of flour yet wol I yeue hem bren
The grettest clerkes been noght the wisest men
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the mare
Of al hir art counte I noght a tare
Out of the dore he gooth ful pryuely
Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
He looketh vp and doun til he hath founde
The clerkes hors ther as it stood ybounde
Bihynde the Mille vnder a leefsel
And to the hors he gooth hym faire and wel
He strepeth of the bridel right anon
And whan the hors was laus he gynneth gon
Toward the fen ther wilde mares renne
And forth with wehe thurgh thikke and thenne
This Millere gooth ayein no word he seyde
But dooth his note and with the clerkes pleyde
Til that hir corn was faire and wel ygrounde
And whan the mele was sakked and ybounde
This Iohn gooth out and fynt his hors away
And gan to crye harrow and weilaway
Oure hors is lost. Alayn for goddes banes
Step on thy feet com of man al atanes
Allas oure wardeyn has his palfrey lorn
This Alayn al forgat bothe mele and corn
Al was out of his mynde his housbondrye
What whilk wey is he gane he gan to crye
The wyf cam lepyng Inward with a ren
She seyde allas youre hors gooth to the fen
With wilde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthank come on his hand that boond hym so
And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne
Allas quod Iohn Aleyn for Cristes peyne
Lay doun thy swerd and I wol myn alswa
I is ful wight god waat as is a ra
By god hert he sal nat scape vs bathe
Be cockis herte he shal not a scape vs bathe
Why ne had thow pit the capil in the lathe
Ilhail by god Alayn thow is a fonne
This sely clerkes haan ful faste yronne
Toward the fen bothe Alayn and eek Iohn
And whan the Millere seigh that they were gon
He half a busshel of hir flour hath take
And bad his wyf go knede it in a cake
He seyde I trowe the clerkes were aferd
Yet kan a Millere maken a clerkes berd
For al his art ye lat hem goon hir weye
Lo wher he gooth ye lat the children pleye
They gete hym noght so lightly by my croun
Thise sely clerkes rennen vp and doun
With keep keep stand stand Iossa warderere
Ga whistle thow and I sal kepe hym heere
But shortly til that it was verray nyght
They koude noght thogh they dide al hir myght
Hir capyl cacche he ran alwey so faste
Til in a dych they caughte hym at the laste
Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
Comth sely Iohn and with hym comth Aleyn
Allas quod Iohn the day that I was born
Now ar we dryuen til hethyng and til scorn
Oure corn is stole men wil vs foolis calle
Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawes alle
And namely the Millere weilawey
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he gooth by the wey
Toward the Mille and Bayard in his hond
The Millere sittyng by the fyr he fond
For it was nyght and ferther myghte they noght
But for the loue of god they hym bisoght
Of herberwe and of ese as for hir peny
The Millere seide agayn if ther be eny
Swich as it is yet shal ye haue youre part
Myn hous is streyt but ye han lerned art
Ye kan by argumentz make a place
A myle brood of twenty foot of space
Lat se now if this place may suffise
Or make it rowm with speche as is your gyse
Now Symond seyde this Iohn by Seint Cutberd
Ay is thou myrie and that is faire answerd
I haue herd seye men sal tak of twa thynges
Swilk as he fyndes or tak swilk as he brynges
But specialy I pray thee hoost deere
Get vs som mete and drynke and make vs cheere
And we wol payen trewely at the fulle
With empty hand men may none haukes tulle
Lo heere oure siluer redy for to spende
This Millere in to town his doghter sende
For ale and breed and rosted hem a goos
And boond hir hors it sholde namoore go loos
And in his owene chambre hem made a bed
With shetes and with chalons faire yspred
Noght from his owene bed but ten foot or twelue
His doghter hadde a bed al by hir selue
Right in the same chambre by and by
It myghte be no bet and cause why
Ther was no rowmer herberwe in the place
They soupen and they speken hem to solace
And drynken euere stroong ale at the beste
Aboute mydnyght wente they to reste
Wel hath this Millere vernysshed his heed
Ful pale he was for dronke and noght reed
He yexeth and he speketh thurgh the nose
As he were on the quakke or on the pose
To bedde he goth and with hym goth his wyf
As any Iay she light was and iolyf
So was hir ioly whistle wel ywet
The Cradel at hir beddes feet is set
To rokken and to yeue the child to sowke
And whan that dronken al was in the Crowke
To bedde wente the doghter right anon
To bedde gooth Aleyn and also Iohn
Ther nas namoore hem neded no dwale
This Millere hath so wisly bibbed ale
That as an hors he fnorteth in his sleep
Ne of his tayl bihynde he took no keep
His wyf bar hym a burdon a ful strong
Men myghten hir routyng heren a furlong
The wenche routeth eek per compaignye
Aleyn the clerc that herde this melodye
He poked Iohn and seyde slepest thow
Herd thow euere slyk a sang er now
Lo swilk a couplyng is ymel hem alle
A wilde fyr on thair bodyes falle
Wha herkned euere swilk a ferly thyng
Ye they sal haue the flour of il endyng
This lang nyght ther tydes me na reste
But yet na force al sal be for the beste
For Iohn seyde he als euere moot I thryue
If that I may yon wenche wol I swyue
Som esement has lawe shapen vs
For Iohn ther is a lawe that says thus
That gif a man in a point be agreued
That in another he sal be releued
Oure corn is stoln soothly it is na nay
And we han had an ille fit to day
And syn I sal haue naan amendement
Agayn my los I wil haue esement
By goddes saule it sal naan other be
This Iohn answerde Aleyn auyse thee
The Millere is a perilous man he sayde
And if that he out of his sleep abrayde
He myghte doon vs bathe a vileynye
Aleyn answerde I counte hym noght a flye
And vp he rist and by the wenche he crepte
This wenche lay vp righte and faste slepte
Til he so neigh was er she myghte espie
That it hadde been to late for to crie
And shortly for to seyn they were at oon
Now pley Aleyn for I wol speke of Iohn
This Iohn lith stille a furlang wey or two
And to hym self he maketh routhe and wo
Allas quod he this is a wikked Iape
Now may I seyn that I is but an ape
Yet has my felawe som what for his harm
He has the Milleris doghter in his arm
He auntred hym and has his nedes sped
And I lye as a draf sak in my bed
And whan this iape is told another day
I sal ben halden a daf a Cokenay
I wil arise and auntre it by my fayth
Vnhardy is vnsely thus men sayth
And vp he roos and softely he wente
Vn to the Cradel and in his hand it hente
And baar it softe vn to his beddes feet
Soone after this the wyf hir routynt leet
And gan awake and wente hir out to pisse
And cam agayn and gan hir Cradel mysse
And groped heer and ther but she foond noon
Allas quod she I hadde almoost mysgoon
I hadde almoost goon to the clerkes bed
Ey benedicite thanne had I foule ysped
And forth she gooth til she the Cradel fond
She gropeth alwey forther with hir hond
And foond the bed and thoghte noght but good
By cause that the Cradel by it stood

l.seg: And nyste wher sche was for it was derk

div.l: And nyste wher she was for it was derk
But faire and wel she creep in to the clerk
And lyth ful stille and wolde haue caught a sleep
With Inne a while this Iohn the clerk vp leep
And on this goode wyf he leyth on soore
So murie a fyt ne hadde she nat ful yoore
He priketh harde and depe as he were mad
This ioly lyf han thise two clerkes lad
Til that the thridde cok bigan to synge
Aleyn wax wery in the dawenynge
For he hadde swonken al the longe nyght
And seyde fare wel Malyn swete wight
The day is come I may no lenger byde
But euere mo wher so I go or ryde
I is thyn awen clerk so haue I sel
Now deere lemman quod she go farewel
But er thow go o thyng I wol thee telle
Whan that thow wendest homward by the Melle
Right at the entree of the dore bihynde
Thow shalt a Cake of half a busshel fynde
That was ymaked of thyn owene mele
Which that I heelp my sire for to stele
And good lemman god thee saue and kepe
And with that word almoost he gan to wepe
Aleyn vp rist and thoghte er that it dawe
I wol go crepen In by my felawe
And fond the Cradel with his hond anon
By god thoghte he al wrang I haue mysgon
Myn heed is toty of my swynk to nyght
That maketh me that I go noght aright
I woot wel by the Cradel I haue mysgo
Here lyth the Millere and his wyf also
And forth he gooth on twenty deueleway
Vn to the bed ther as the Millere lay
He wende haue cropen by his felawe Iohn
And by the Millere In he creep anoon
And caughte hym by the nekke and softe he spak
He seyde thou Iohn thow swyneshed awak
For cristes saule and here a noble game
For by that lord that called is Seint Iame
As I haue thries in this shorte nyght
Swyued the Milleris doghter bolt vp right
Whil thow hast as a coward been agast
Ye false harlot quod the Millere hast
Ye false harlot hast thou so hest
A false traytour false clerk quod he
Thou shalt be deed by goddes dignytee
Who dorste be so bold to disparage
My doghter that is come of swich lynage
And by the throte bolle he caughte Alayn
And he hente hym despitously agayn
And on the nose he smoot hym with his fest
Doun ran the blody streem vp on his brest
And on the floor with nose and mouth tobroke
They walwen as doon two pigges in a poke
And vp they goon and doun agayn anoon
Til that the Millere sporned on a stoon
And doun he fil bakward vp on his wyf
That wiste no thyng of this nyce stryf
For she was falle aslepe alitel wight
With Iohn the clerk that waked hadde al nyght
And with the fal out of hir sleep she brayde
Help holy cros of Bromholm she sayde
In manus tuas lord to thee I calle
Awake Symond the feend is on me falle
Myn herte is broken help I nam but ded
Ther lyth oon vp on my wombe and vp myn hed
Help Symkyn for the false clerkes fighte
This Iohn sterte vp as faste as euere he myghte
And graspeth by the walles to and fro
To fynde a staf and she sterte vp also
And knew the estres bet than dide this Iohn
And by the wal a staf she foond anon
And saugh a litel shymeryng of a light
For at an hole in shoon the moone bright
And by that light she saugh hem bothe two
But sikerly she nyste who was who
But as she saugh a whit thyng in hir Iye
And whan she gan this white thyng espye
She wende the clerk hadde wered a voluper
And with the staf she drow ay ner and ner
And wende han hit this Aleyn at the fulle
And smoot the Millere on the piled skulle
That doun he gooth and cryde harrow I dye
Thise clerkes bette hym wel and lete hym lye
And greithen hem and tooke hir hors anon
And eek hir mele and on hir wey they gon
And at the Mille yet they toke hir cake
Of half a busshel flour ful wel ybake
Thus is the proude Millere wel ybete
And hath ylost the gryndyng of the whete
And payed for the souper euerydel
Of Aleyn and of Iohn that bette hym wel
His wyf is swyued and his doghter als
Lo which it is a Millere to be fals
And therfore this prouerbe is seyd ful sooth
Hym thar nat wene wel that yuele dooth
A gilour shal hym self bigiled be
And god that sitteth heighe in magestee
Saue al this compaignie grete and smale
Thus haue I quyt the Millere in my tale

¶ The prologe of the Cookes tale
¶ Prologus
The Cook / of Londoun / whil the Reue spak
For ioye hym thoughte / he clawed hym on the bak
Haha quod he / for Cristes passioun
This Millere / hadde a sharpe conclusioun
Vp on his argument of herbergage
Wel seyde Salomon / in his langage
Ne bryng nat euery man / in to thyn hous
For herberwyng by nyghte is perilous
Wel oghte a man / auysed for to be
Whom that he broghte / in to his priuetee
I pray to god / so yeue me sorwe and care
If euer sith / I highte hogge of ware
Herde I a Millere / bettre yset awerk
He hadde a iape of malice / in the derk
But god forbede / that we stynten heere hic
For if ye / vouche sauf to heere audire
A tale of me / that am a poure man
I wol yow telle / as wel as euere I kan
A litel iape / that fil in oure Citee
¶ Oure hoost answerde / and seyde I graunte it thee
Now tel on Roger / looke that it be good
For many a pastee / hastow laten blood
And many a Iakke of Douere / hastow soold
That hath been twies hoot and twies coold
Of many a pilgrym / hastow Cristes curs
For of thy presle / yet they fare the wors
That they han eten / with thy stubbul goos
For in thy shoppe / is many a flye loos
Now tel on / gentil Roger / by thy name
But yet I praye thee / be nat wrooth for game
A man may seye ful sooth / in game and pley
¶ Thow seist ful sooth / quod Roger by my fey
But sooth pley quade pley / as the Flemyng seith
And therfore herry Bailly / by thy feith
Be thou nat wrooth / er we departen heer
Thogh that my tale / be of an hostiler
But nathelees / I wol nat telle it yit
But er we parte / ywis thow shalt be quyt
And ther with al / he lough / and made cheere
And seyde his tale / as ye shal after heere
Here endeth the prologe .
¶ Here bigynneth the Cook his tale
Narrat
A Prentis / whilom dwelled in oure Citee
And of a craft of vitaillers was he
Gaillard he was / as goldfynch in the shawe
Broun as a berye / a propre short felawe
With lokkes blake / ykembd ful fetisly
Dauncen he koude / so wel and iolily
That he / was clepyd Perkyn Reuelour
He was / as ful / of loue and paramour
As is the hyue / ful of hony swete
Wel was the wenche / that with hym myghte meete
At euery bridale / wolde he synge and hoppe
He loued bet the Tauerne / than the shoppe
For / whan ther any ridyng was in Chepe
Out of the shoppe / thider wolde he lepe
Til that he hadde / al the sighte yseyn
And daunced wel / he wolde noght come ageyn
And gadred hym / a meynee of his sort
To hoppe and synge / and maken swich disport
With Rechneuer and recheles þis lesson he lerys
With waste and with wranglere his owne pley ferys
With lytghthonde and with lykorouse mowth with vnschamfast
With drynke more ⁊ with drawe a bak her thryst is y past
With malaperte ⁊ with mysseavysed suche meyny þey hight
That wolle do but a lytul tylle her dyuer bedyght
And ther / they setten steuene / for to meete
To pleyen at the dees / in swich a Streete
For in the town / nas ther no Prentys
That fairer / koude caste a paire of dys
Than Perkyn koude / and ther to he was free
Of his dispense / in place of pryuetee
With Magot ⁊ with Mylsent whan þat he mette
The bagge with þe powder anon was vnknette
His purs was inperfit he couthe notwelle kepe
Yet let vs be mery while oure sire is aslepe
With Pyes ⁊ with Pykrels with wyues moste swete
With loche ⁊ with lamprey þe childe myght not ete
The Tapster þe Taverner þe koke was nedy
Wolde clepe on perkyn for his purs was so redy
That foond his maister wel / in his chaffare
For ofte tyme / he foond his box ful bare
For euery other day his boxe was lefte bare
For sikerly / a prentys reuelour
An vnthrysty begynnyng for yong or for olde
That haunteth dees / ryot or paramour
A Prentyse to be a reueloure ⁊ peramours to holde
His maister / shal it in his shoppe abye
That bargeyn no man so sore schalle Abye
Al haue he / no part of the Minstralcye
As his Maister þat hath no parte of his melodye
For thefte and riot / they been couertible
Al konne he pleye / on Giterne / or Rubible
Reuel and trouthe / as in a lowe degree
They been ful wrothe al day / as men may see
When þy purs is penyles where schalt þou haue more
Thou þat wylt not þe ottupie no thyng therfore
Revel ys ordeyned to hem þat mow pay
But prentise ne pore man þey mowe not away
Euelle sponne wolle at the laste wolle come oute
They þou kepe it neuer so prevey in alytelle cloute
¶ This ioly Prentys / with his Maister bood
Til he were neigh / out of his prentishood
Al were he snybbed / bothe erly and late
And som tyme / lad with reuel to Newgate
Where he his vnthriftynes sore aboughte
But atte laste / his maister hym bithoghte
Vpon a day / whan he his papir soghte
To over se his papire ⁊ hym thorow sought
Of a prouerbe / that seith this same word
Wel bet is roten Appul / out of hoord
Than that it rotte / al the remenaunt
So fareth it by a riotous seruaunt
It is ful lasse harm / to lete hym pace
Than he shende / alle the seruantz in the place
Euen as a stabbed schepe in þe folde
Alle a flocke wolle defyle both yonge ⁊ olde
Ryght euen so a febel seruaunt may
Distruye fourty of his felaws in a day
Therfore / his maister gaf hym acquitaunce
And bad hym go / with sorw / and with meschaunce
Better ys betyme to voyde suche a clerke
The lenger he abydeth þe wors is his werke
He þat his Maister no profite wolle wynne
Y holde hym better out of þe hous þan with ynne
And thus this ioly prentys / hadde his leeue
Now lat hym riote / al the nyght or leeue
And for ther nys no theef withoute a lowke
That helpeth hym / to wasten and to sowke
Of that he brybe kan / or borwe may
Anon / he sente his bed / and his array
Vnto a compeer / of his owene sort
That loued dees / and reuel / and disport
And hadde a wyf / that heeld for contenaunce
A shoppe / and swyued for hir sustenaunce

¶ Incipit Fabula de Gemelyn
NOw lithe and lystenyth so god geue you goode fyne
And ye schulle here gode game of yonge Gamelyne
xxiiij an yongemen that helde hem ful bolde
Lithen and lystenyth and herkenyth aright
And ye shul heren of a doughty knyght
Syr Iohn of Boundis was his name
He coude of norture and mochel of game
Thre sones the knyght had and with his body he hem wan
The eldest was a moche shrewe and sone he began
His brothern loued wele hir Fader and of hym were agast
The eldest deserued his Faders curs and had it at last
The good knyght his Fader leued so yore
That deth was comen hym and handlyd hym ful sore
The good knyght cared sore sike there he lay
How his children shuld lyuen after his day
He hadde ben wyde where but noon husbond he was
Alle the londe that he had it was verrey purchas
Fayn he wolde it were drissed amonge hem alle
That iche of hem had his part as it myght falle
Thoo sent he into the contre after wyse knyghtes
To helpe delen his londes and dressen hem to rightes
He sente hem worde by lettres to highe blyve
Yf they wolde speke with hym while he was on lyve
The knyghtes herden seke that he lay
Had they no reste neyther nyght ne day
Til they comen to hym ther he lay stille
On his dethbedde to abyde goddes wille
Than seyde the good knyght sike ther he lay
Lordes I yow warne forsothe withouten nay
I may no lenger leve here in this stounde
For though goddes wille deth draweth me to grounde
Ther nas noon of hem alle that harde hym aright
That thay hadden routhe of that ilke knyght
And seyde sire forgoddis loue dismay yow nought
God may don bote of bale that is now I wrought
Than spak the good knyght sike ther he lay
Bote of bale god may sende I wote it is no nay
But I beseke yow knyghtes for the loue of me
Gooth and dresseth my londes amonge my sones thre
And for the loue of god deleth hem not amys
And forgete not Gamelyn my yonge son that is
Taketh heed he to that oon as wele as to that other
Selde ye see any Eier helpen his brother
Thoo leten they the knyght lyen that was nat in hele
And wenten into consel his londes footo dele
For to delen hem alle to oon that was her thought
And For Gamelyn was yongest he sholde haue nought
Alle the londe that ther was they dalten it in twoo
And lete Gamelyn the yonge with outen londe goo
And eche of hem saide til other ful loude
His brothern mowe yeve hym londe when he good coude
Whan they had delyd the londe at hire owne wille
They come to the knyght ther he lay ful stille
And tolde hym anoon how they hadde wrought
And the knyght ther he lay lyked it right nought
Than seyde the knyght be seint Martyn
For al that ye haue don yet is the lond myn
For goddes loue neighbours stondeth alle stille
And I wole delen myn lond at myn owen wille
Iohn myn Eldest sone shal haue plowes fyve
That was my faders heritage while he was on lyve
And my myddelest sone fyve plowes londe
That I halpe to geten with my right honde
And alle my other purchas of londes and ledes
That I be quethe Gamelyn and alle my good stedes
And I beseke yow good men that lawe kan of londe
For Gamelynes loue that my quest stonde
Thus dalt the knyght his londe by his day
Right on his deth bedde sike ther he lay
And sone afterwarde he lay stone stille
And deide whan tyme come as it was cristis wille
Anoon as he was deed and vnder gras graue
Sone the eldere brothere bygiled the yonge knaue
He toke into his hoond his londe and his lede
And Gamelyn hym silfe to clothe and to fede
He clothed hym and fedde hym wel and eke wroth
And lete his londes forfare and his houses both
His parkes and his wodes and did nothyng wel
And sithen he hit aboughte in his faire fel
So longe was Gamelyn in his brothers halle
For the strengest of good wille thei doutide hym alle
Ther was noon ther Inne noyer yonge ne olde
That wolde wrath Gamelyn were he neuer so bolde
Gamelyn stood on a day in his brotheres yerde

He thought on his londes that layn vnsawe
And his faire Okes that doun were drawe
His Park were broken and his dere reued
Of alle his good stedes noon was hym byleued
Hise houses were vnhelyd and fulle Ille dight
Thoo thought Gamelyn it went nought a right
Aftirward cam his brother walkyng thare
And saide to Gamelyn is our mete yare
Tho Gamelyn wrathed hym and swore by goddes boke
Thow shalt goo bake thy selfe I wil not be thy coke
How brother Gamelyn answerst thow now
Thow spak neuer suche a worde as thow dost now
By my faith saide Gamelyn now me thenketh nede
Of alle the harmes that I haue I toke neuer are hede
Myn parkes ben broken and my dere ben reved

Alle that my fader me bequath al goth to shame

Than bespak his brother that rape was of rees
Stonde stille Gadlyng and holde right thy pees

What spekest thow Gamelyn of londe oyer of lede

Than saide the childe yonge Gamelyn
Cristis curs mote thow haue brother art thow myn

Whan euer y of hem hadde a staffe I nomen
Gamelyn was ware thoo he saugh hem comen
Tho Gamelyn seigh hem comen he loked ouer al
And was ware of a pestel stode vnder a walle
Gamelyn was light and theder gan he lepe

Some for Gamelyns loue and som for his eie

What now seid Gamelyn euel mote ye the
Wille ye bygynne contek and so sone fle
Gamelyn sought his brother whither he was flowe

Brother saide Gamelyn come a litel nere

And wente with moche Ioye hom in the mornyng
His brother sey where he come with the grete route
And badde shitte the gate and holde hym with oute
The porter of his lorde was as sore agaste
And sterte anoon to the gate and loked it faste
Now litheth and lysteneth bothe yonge and olde
And ye schul here gamen of Gamelyn the bolde
Gamelyn come therto forto haue come In
Than was it shet fast with a pyn
Than saide Gamelyn porter vndoo the yate
For many good mannys sone stond ther ate
Than answerd the porter and swor by goddes berd
Thou ne shalt Gamelyn come into this yerd
Thow lixt said Gamelyn so broke I my chynne
He smate the wyket with his foot and broke a way the pynne
The porter saugh thoo it myght no better bee
He set foot on erthe he began to flee
By my faith saide Gamelyn that trauaile is lore
For I am on fote as light as thow though thow haddest swore
Gamelyn ouertoke the porter and his tene wrak
And gert hym in the nek that the boon to brak
And took hym by that oon arme and threwe hym in a welle
700 fadom hyt was depe as I haue herd telle
Whan Gamelyn the yonge thus had plaied his play
Alle that in the yerde were drewen hem a way
That dreden hym ful sore for wreke that he wrought
And for the faire company that he theder brought
Gamelyn yede to the gate and lete vp wide
He lete Inne alle that goon wolde or ride
And saide ye ben welcome with outen any greue
For we wille ben maistres here and aske noman leue
Yester day I lefte saide yonge Gamelyn
In my brother seler fyue tonne of wyn
I wil not this company part on twynne
And ye wil don after me while any sope is Inne
And if I my brother grucche or make foule chere
Other for spence of mete and drynke that we spende here
I am oure catour and bere oure aller purs
He shal haue for his grucchyng seint Maries curs
My brother is a nygon I swere by cristis ore
And we wille spende largely that he hath spared yore
And who that maketh grucchyng that we here dwelle
He shal to the porter into the drawe welle
Vij daies and vij nyght Gamelyn helde his feste
With moche solace that there was and no cheste
In a lytel toret his brother lay steke
And saugh hym wast his good but durst he not speke
Erly on a mornyng on the viij day
The gestes come to Gamelyn and wold goon her way
Lordes saide Gamelyn wil ye so hie
Alle the wyn is not yet dronked so broke I myn eye
Gamelyn in hys hert was wele woo
Whan his gestes toke her leve fro hym forto goo
He wolde they hadde dwelled lenger and thay saide nay
But bitaught Gamelyn to god and bad hym good day
Thus made Gamelyn his feste and brought it wele to ende
And after his gestes toke leue to wende
Litheth and lysteneth and holdeth youre tonge
And ye shul here gamen of Gamelyn the yonge
Herkeneth lordynges and lysteneth a right
Whan alle gestis were goon how Gamelyn was dight
Alle the while that Gamelyn helde his mangerie
His brother thought on hym be wreke with his trecherie
Tho Gamelynes gestes weren riden and goon
Gamelyn stode anoon allone frendes hadde he non
Tho after fulsone with Inne a litel stounde
Gamelyn was taken and ful harde I bounde
Forth come the fals knyght oute of the selere
To Gamelyn his brother he yede ful nere
And saide to Gamelyn whoo made the so bolde
For to stroyen my store of my houssolde
Brother saide Gamelyn wrath the right nought
For it is many day gon sith it was bought
For brother thow hast had by seint richere
Of xv plowes of londe this xvj yere
And of alle the bestes thow haste forth bred
That my fader me bequath in his deed bed
Of alle this vxj yere I yeue the the prowe
For the mete and the drynke that we haue spended nowe
Than saide the fals knyght euel mote he the
Herken brother Gamelyn what I wole yeue the
For of my body brother geten eier haue I noon
I wil make the myn eier I swere be seint Iohn
Thermaffay saide Gamelyn and it so be
And thow thynke as thow saist god yelde it the
Nothyng wiste Gamelyn of his brotheris gile
Therfore he hym bygyled in a litel while
Gamelyn seyde he othyng I the telle
Thogh thou threwe my porter in to the drawe welle
I swore in that wrath and in that grete mote
That thow sholdest be bounden both hande and fote
Therfore I the beseche brother Gamelyn
Lat me nought be forsworne brother artow myn
Lat me bynde the bothe hand and foote
Forto halden myn avough as I the behote
Brother saide Gamelyn as so mote I the
Thow shalt not ben forswore for the love of me
Tho made they Gamelyn to sitte myght he not stonde
Til they hadde hym bounden bothe foot and honde
The fals knyght his brother of Gamelyn was agaste
And sente after feters to fetren hym faste
His brother made lesynges on hym there he stood
And tolde hem that comen Inne that Gamelyn was wood
Gamelyn stood to a poste bounden in the halle
That tho comen Inne loked on hym alle
Euer stood Gamelyn euen vpright
But mete nor drynke hadde he noon neyther day ne nyght
That saide Gamelyn brother by my hals
Now I haue aspied thow art a party fals
Hadde I wyst that tresou that thow hast founde
I wolde haue stroken or I hadde ben bounde
Gamelyn stood bounden stille as any stoon
Too daies and too nyghtes mete hadde he noon
Than saide Gamelyn that stode Ibounde stronge
Adam spencer me thynke I faste to longe
Adam spencer now I beseche thee
For the moche loue my fader loued thee
If thow may come to the kayes lese me oute of bonde
And I wille parte with the of my fre londe
Than saide Adam that was the spencer
I haue serued thy brother this xvj yere
Yf I lete the goon oute of his boure
He wolde say aftirward y were a traitoure
Adam saide Gamelyn so broke I myn hals
Thow shalt fynde my brother atte last right fals
Therfore brother Adam lose me oute of bondes
And I wille part with the of my fre londes
Vp swiche a forward seide Adam I wis
I wille do therto al that in me is
Adam seide Gamelyn also mote I the
I wole holde the couenaunt and thow wil me
A noon as Adames lorde to bedde was goon
Adam toke the keyes and lete Gamelyn oute anoon
He vnlokked Gamelyn bothe handes and feet
In hope of avauncement that he hym behete
Than saide Gamelyn thonked be goddes sonde
Now am I louse both foot and honde
Hadde I now eten and dronken aright
Ther is noon in this house shuld bynde me this nyght
Adam took Gamelyn stille as any stone
And hadde hym into spence rapely anone
And sette hym to soper right in a preuy stede
And bad hym do gladly and gamelyn so dede
A noon as Gamelyn hadde eten wele and fyn
And therto I dronke wele of the rede wyn
Adam saide Gamelyn what is now thy rede
For I goo to my brother and girde of his hede
Gamelyn saide Adam it shal not be soo
I can teche the a rede that is worth the too
I wote wele forsoth that this is no nay
We shul haue a mangye right on sonday
Abbotes and priours many here shal be
And other men of holy chirche as I telle the
Thow shalt stonde vp by the post as thow were honde faste
And I shal tham leue vnlokke that a way thow may hem cast
Whan that they haue eten and wasshen here hondes
Thow shalt beseke hem alle to brynge the oute of bondes
And if they wille borow the that were good game
Than were thow oute of prisou and I oute of blame
And if iche of hem say to vs nay
I shal don another I swere by this day
Thow shalt haue a good staf and I wille a nother
And cristis curs haue that oon that faileth that other
Ya forgod saide Gamelyn I say it for me
Yf I faile on my side euel mote I the
Yf we shul algate assoile hem of hir synne
Warne me brother Adam whan we shul begynne
Gamelyn saide Adam be seint Charite
I wole warne the beforn whan that shal be
Whan I thenke on the loke forto goon
And caste away the feters and come to me anoon
Adam saide Gamelyn blyssed be thy bones
That is a good counsaile yeuyng for the nones
Yf they werne me to brynge oute of bendes
I wole sette good strokes right on there lendes
Thoo the sonday was come and folke to the feste
Faire thay were welcome both mest and leste
And euer as they atte halle dore come In
They caste theire eye on yonge Gamelyn
The fals knyght his brother and ful of trecherie
And alle the gestes that there were atte mangerie
Of Gamelyn his brother he tolde hem with mouthe
Alle the harme and the shame that he telle couthe
Thoo they were serued of meses too or three
Than saide Gamelyn how serue ye me
It is not wele serued be god that alle made
That I sitte fastynge and outher men make glade
The fals knyght his brother there that he stood
Tolde alle his gestes that Gamelyn was wood
And Gamelyn stood stille and answerid nought
But Adames wordes he helde in his thought
So Gamelyn gan speke doulefully withalle
Tho the grete lordes that satyn in the halle
Lordes he saide for cristis passiou
Helpe to brynge Gamelyn oute of prisou
Than saide an Abbot sorow on his cheke
He shal haue cristis curs and saint Maries eke
That the oute of prisou beggeth or borowe
But euer worth hym wele that doth the mykel sorowe
After that Abbot than spak another
I wolde thyn hede were of they thow were my brother
Alle that the borwe foule mote hem falle
Thus thay saide alle that were in the halle
Than sayde a priour euel mote he thryue
It is moche sorow and scathe both that thow art on lyue
Ow saide Gamelyn so broke I my bone
Now I haue aspied that frendes haue I noone
Cursed mote he worthe both fleissh and blood
That euer doth Priour or Abbot any good
Adam the spencer toke vp the clooth
And loked on Gamelyn and saugh that he was wrooth
Adam of the Pantrie lytul he thought
But too good staues to the halle dore he brought
Adam loked on Gamelyn and he was ware anoon
And caste away the feteres and gan to goon
Thoo he come to Adam he toke the to staf
And began to worche and good strokes yaf
Gamelyn come into the halle and the spencer bothe
And loked hem aboute as they hadde ben wrothe
Gamelyn sprenet holy water with an oken spire
That som that stood vpright fille into the fire
Ther was no leude man that in the halle stode
That wolde do Gamelyn any thyng but gode
But stonden besiden and lete hem bothe werche
For they hadde no routhe of men of men of holy cherche
Abbot or Priour Monke or Chanou
That Gamelyn ouer toke anoon they yeden dou
Ther was noon of hem alle that with his staf mette
That he made hem ouerthrowe and quitte hem his dette
Gamelyn saide Adam for saint charite
Pay good lyueray for the loue of me
And I wole kepe the dore so euer here I masse
Or they ben assoilled ther shal noon passe
Dought the nought saide Gamelyn while we ben in fere
Kepe thow wele the dore and I wole werche here
Stere good Adam and lat there noon flee
And we shulle telle largely how mony ther be
Gamelyn saide Adam doo hem but good

l.seg: But Gamelyn sayd adam do hem but goode

div.l: They ben men of holy chirche drawe of hem no blood
Saue wele the crowne and doo hem noo harmes
But breke both her legges and sithen her armes
Thus Gamelyn and Adam wrought right faste
And pleyde with the Monkes and made hem agaste
Theder they come rydyng Iolyly with swaynes
And hom ayein they were ledde in cartis and in waynes
Tho they hadde alle y don than saide a gray frere
Allas ser Abbot what dyd we here
Tho that we come heder it was a cold rede
Vs hadde ben better at home with water and with brede
While Gamelyn made ordres of Monkes and frere
Euere stode his brother and made foule chere
Gamelyn vp with his staf that he wele knewe
And grette hym in the nekke that he ouer threwe
A litel a boue the girdel the riggebon to barst
And sette in the fetters hym ther he sat arst
Sitte there brother saide Gamelyn
Forto Colyn thy body as I did myn
As swithe as they had wroken hem on her fon
They asked water and wisshen anon
What som for hire loue and som for awe
Alle the seruantes serued hem of the best lawe
The sheriff was then but fyue myle
And alle was tolde hym in a lytel whyle
How Gamelyn and Adam had don a sory res
Bounden and wounden men ayen the kynges pees
Tho began sone stryfe forto wake
And the sherif aboute Gamelyn Forto take
Now litheth and lysteneth so god yeue yow good fyne
And ye shul here good game of yonge Gamelyn
Foure and twenty yonge men that holden hem ful bolde
Come to the sheref and saide that they wolde
Gamelyn and Adam fette be the way
The sheref gaf hem leue soth as I yow say
They hyeden faste wolde they nat lynne
Til they come to the gate there Gamelyn was Inne
They knocken on the gate the porter was nye
And loked oute at an hole as man that was slye
The Porter hadde beholde them a litel while
He loued wele Gamelyn and was drad of Gile
And lete the wyket stonde ful stille
And asked hem with oute what was her wille
For alle the grete company than spak but oon
Vndoo the gate porter and late vs Inne goon
Than saide the porter so broke I my chynne
Ye shul say youre erand er that ye come Inne
Say to Gamelyn and Adam if thaire wille be
We wil speke with hym too wordes or thre
Felawe saide the Porter stonde there stille
And I wolle wende to Gamelyn to wete his wille
Inne wente the Porter to Gamelyn anoon
And saide sir I warne yow here become youre foon
The shereffes men now ben atte the gate
Forto take yow bothe shul ye not skape
Porter saide Gamelyn so mote I wele thee
I wille allowe the thy wordes whan I my tyme see
Go agayn to the gate and dwelle with hem a while
And thow shalt see right sone porter agile
Adam saide Gamelyn loke the to goon
We haue foomen atte gate and frendes neuer oon
It ben the shireffes men that heder ben I come
They ben swore to gider that we shul be nome
Gamelyn saide Adam hye the right blyue
And if I faile the thys day euel mote I thryue
And we shul so welcome the shereffes men
That som of hem shal make her beddes in the fen
Atte posterne gate Gamelyn oute wente
And a good cartestaf in his honde he hente
Adam hent sone another grete staf
Forto helpe Gamelyn and good strokes he gaf
Adam felled twayne and Gamelyn felled three
The tother sette feet on erthe and began to flee
What saide Adam so euer here I masse
I haue good wyn drynke or ye passe
Nay bygod saide thay thy drynke is not good
It wolde make mannys brayn to lyen in his hood
Gamelyn stode stille and loked aboute
A saide he the sheref cometh with a grete route
Adam seide Gamelyn what be now thy redes
Here cometh the scherreue and wil haue oure heedes
Adam saide to Gamelyn my rede is now this
Abide we no lenger if we fare amys
I rede that wee to wood goon or that we be founde
Better is there loos than in toun I bounde
Adam toke by the hoond yong Gamelyn
And euer y of hem dranke a draught of wyn
And after toke hire cours and wenten her way
Thoo fonde the sheref nest but non Ay
The sheref light doun and went into the halle
And fonde the lorde fetered fast with alle
The shiref vnfeterid hym right sone anoon
And sente after a leche to hele his rigge bon
Lete we now the fals knyght lye in his care
And telle we of Gamelyn and loke how he fare
Gamelyn into the wood stalked stille
And Adam Spencer loked right ille
Adam swore to Gamelyn be seint richere
Now I see it is mery to be a Spencere
That leuer me were keyes to bere
Than walken in this wilde wood my clothes to tere
Adam saide Gamelyn dismay the right nought
Many good mannys childe in care is brought
And they toke talkyng bothen in fere
Adam herde talkyng of men and neigh hym thought they were
Tho Gamelyn loked vnder wood aright
Vij score of yonge men he sey wele I dight
Alle satte atte mete compas aboute
Adam saide Gamelyn now haue ye no doute
After bale comes bete thorgh goddes myght
Me thenketh of mete and drynke I haue a sight
Adam loked thoo vnder wood lowe
And tho he say mete he was glad I nowe
For he hoped to god for to haue his dele
And he was sore alonged after agood mele
As he say that word the maister outlawe
Saw Gamelyn and Adam vnder wood shawe
Yonge men saide the maister by the good rood
I am ware of gestes god send vs good
Yond be too yonge men right wele adight
And perauenture they ben moo who so loked aright
Ariseth vp yonge men and fette hem to mee
It is good that wee weten what men thay bee
Vp they stirten vij fro the dynere
And metten with Gamelyn and Adam spencere
Whan they were neygh hem than saide that one
Yeldeth vp yonge men youre bowes and youre flone
Than saide Gamelyn that yonge was of elde
Moche sorow mote they haue that to yow yelde
I curse noon other but right my selfe
Tho ye fette to yow fyve than be ye twelfe
That they harde by his worde that myght was in his arme
There was noon of hem that wolde don hym harme
But saide vnto Gamelyn myldely and stille
Come a fore oure maister and say to hym thy wille
Yonge men saide Gamelyn be your lewte
What man is youre maister that ye with be
Alle they answerd with oute lesyng
Oure maister is crowned of outlawes kyng
Adam saide Gamelyn goo we in cristis name
He may nother mete noo drynke to werne vs for shame
And that he be hende and come of gentil blood
He wil yeue vs mete and drynke and do vs som good
Be saint Iame said Adam what harme that I gete
I wil auenture me to the dore that I had mete
Gamelyn and Adam went forth in fere
And they grette the maister that they fonde there
Than saide the maister kyng of outlawes
What seke ye yonge men vnder wode shawes
Gamelyn answerd the kyng with his crowne
He most nede walke in wodes that may not walke in towne
Sir we walke not here noon harm to doo
But if we mete a dere to shete thertoo
As men that ben hungry and mow no mete fynde
And ben harde bystad / vnder the wood lynde
Of Gamelyn wordes the maister had reuthe
And saide ye shal haue Inow haue god my treuth
He badde hem sytte doun forto take reste
And bad hem ete and drynke / and that of the best
As they eten and dronken wele and fyn
Than saide the toon to the tother this is Gamelyn
Tho was the maister outlawe into counseil nome
And tolde how it was Gamelyn that theder was come
Anoon as he herd how it was byfalle
He made hym maister vnder hym ouer hem alle
With Inne the thrid weke hym come tydyng
To the maister outlawe that was her kyng
That he sholde come home his pees was made
And of that good tydyng he was ful glade
Thoo saide he to his yonge men soth for to telle
Me becomen tydynges I may no lenger dwelle
Thoo was Gamelyn anoon with oute tariyng
Made maister outlawe and crowned her kyng
Thoo was Gamelyn crowned kyng of outlawes
And walked a while vnder wode shawes
The fals knyght his brother was shiref and sire
And lete his brother endite for hate and ire
Thoo were his bonde men sory and nothyng glad
Whan Gamelyn her lorde wolfes heed was cried and mad
And sente oute of his men where they myght hym fynd
Forto seke Gamelyn vnder wode lynde
To telle hym tydynges the wynde was went
And alle his good reued and his men shent
Whan thay hadde hym founden on knees they hem setten
And adoun with hire hood and hire lorde gretten
Sire wrath yow nought for the good rode
For we haue brought yow tydynges but they ben not gode
Now is thy brother shiref and hath the baillye
And hath endited thee and wolfes heed dooth the crie
Allas saide Gamelyn that euer I was so slak
That I ne hadde broke his nekke whan I his rigge brak
Goth greteth wele myn housbondes and wyf
I wille ben atte next shire haue god my lyf
Gamelyn cam wele redy to the next shire
And there was his brother both lorde and syre
GAmelyn come boldeliche into the mote halle
And put adoun his hood amonge the lordes alle
God saue yow lordynges that now here bee
But brokebak shiref evel mote thow thee
Why hastow don me that shame and vylonye
Forto late endite me and wolfes heed me crye
Tho thought the fals knyght to ben a wreke
And lete take Gamelyn most he nomore speke
Moste ther be no grace but Gamelyn atte last
Was cast in prisou and fetered ful fast
Gamelyn hath a brother that hight sir ote
As gode a knyght and hende as myght gon on fote
Anoon yede a massagere to that good knyght
And tolde hym altogedir how Gamelyn was dight
Anoon as sir Ote herde how Gamelyn was dight
He was right sory was he nought lyght
And lete sadle a stede and the waye he name
And to his too brethern right sone he came
Sir saide sir Ote to the Shiref thoo
We ben three brethern shal we be neuer moo
And thus hast thow prisoned the best of vs alle
Suche another brother euel mote hym byfalle
Sir Ote saide the fals knyght late be thy curs
By god for thy wordes he shal fare the wurs
To the kynges prisou he is I nome
And yet he shal abide tille the Iustice come
Parde saide ser Ote better it shal be
I bidde hym to maymprise that thow graunte me
Tille next sittynge of delyueraunce
And late than Gamelyn stonde at his chaunce
Brother in suche a forward I take hym to the
And by thy faders soule that the bygate and me
But he be redy whan the Iustice sitte
Thow shalt bere the Iugement for alle thy grete witte
I graunte wele saide ser Ote that it so be
Late delyuere hym anoon and take hym to me
Tho was Gamelyn delyuered to ser Ote his brother
And that nyght dwelled the toon with the tother
On the morne saide Gamelyn to ser Ote the hende
Brother he saide I forsoth I mote fro the wende
To loke how my yonge men lede her lyfe
Whether they lyfen in Ioye or in stryfe
By god saide ser Ote that is a colde rede
Now I see that alle the Carke shal falle on my hede
For whan the Iustice sitte and thow be not I founde
I shal anoon be take and in thy steed I bounde
Brother saide Gamelyn dismaye the nought
For be seint Iame in Gales yt many man hath sought
If that god almyghty holde me my lyfe and my witte
I wille be there redy whan the Iustice sitte
Than saide ser Ote to Gamelyn god shelde the fro shame
Come whan thow seist tyme and brynge vs oute of blame
Lith and listeneth and holde yow stille
And ye shulle here how Gamelyn had his wille
Gamelyn went vnder wood rise
And fonde there plaiyng yong men of prise
Thoo was yonge Gamelyn right glad Inow
Whan he fonde his men vnder wood bow
Gamelyn and his men talked I fere
And thay had good game hire maister to here
His men tolde hym of aventures that they had founde
A Gamelyn hem tolde ayein how he was faste bounde
While Gamelyn was outlawe had he no curs
Ther was noman that for hym ferde the wurs
But Abbottis and Priours Monke and Chanoun
On hem left he nought whan he myght hem nome
While Gamelyn and his men made myrthes ryue
The fals knyght his brother euel mote he thryue
For he aboute bothe day and other
Forto hire the quest to hangen his brother
Gamelyn stood on a day and he byhelde
The wodes and the shawes in the wild felde
He thought on his brother how he hym behete
That he wolde be redy whan the Iustice sete
He thought wele that he wolde with oute delay
Come afore þe Iustice to keepen his day
Come a fore the Iustice with oute delay
And saide to his yonge men dighteth yow yare
For whan the Iustice sitte we most be thare
For I am vnder borwe til that I come
And my brother for me to prisou shal be nome
Be saint Iame saide his yonge men and thow rede ther to
Ordeyne how it shal be and it shal be doo
While Gamelyn was comyng ther the Iustice satte
The fals knyght his brother forgate he not thatte
To hire then men on his quest to hangen his brother
Thow they hadde not that oon he wolde had that other
Thoo come Gamely fro vnder wood rise
And brought with hym yonge men of prise
I se wele saide Gamelyn the Iustice is sette
Goo a forn Adam and loke how it spette
Adam wente into the halle and loked alle aboute
He sawe stonde there lordes grete and stoute
And ser Otes his brother fetered wele fast
Tho went Adam oute of the halle as he were agast
Adam saide to Gamelyn and to his felawes alle
Sir Ote stant fetered in the mote halle
Yonge men sayde Gamelyn this they heeren alle
Sire Ote stant fetered in the moot hall
Yf god yeue vs grace wele forto doo
He shal it abigge that it brought ther too
Than saide Adam that lokkes had hore
Cristis curs mote he haue that bound hym so sore
And thow wilt Gamelyn don after myn rede
There is non in the halle shal bere a way his heede
Adam saide Gamelyn we wil not doo soo
We wille slee the giltife and lete the other goo
I wille into the halle and here the Iustice speke
On hem that ben gilty I wil ben awreke
Late noon scape atte dore take yonge men yeme
For I wille be Iustice this day domes to deme
God spede me this day at my newe werke
Adam come with me for thow shalt be my clerke
His men answerd hym and bad hym don his best
And if thow to vs haue nede thow shalt fynd vs prest
We wille stande with the while that we may dure
But we werke manly pay vs no hure
Yonge men saide Gamelyn so mote I the
As trusty a maister ye shul fynd of me
Right there the Iustice satte in the halle
Inne went Gamelyn amonge hem alle
Gamelyn lete vnfet ere his brother oute of bende
Than saide ser Ote his brother that was hende
Thow haddist almost Gamelyn dwelled to longe
For the quest is oute of me that I sholde honge
Brother saide Gamelyn so god yeue me good rest
This day thay shul ben hanged that ben on thy quest
And the Iustice bothe that is the Iugge man
And the shiref both thorow hym it began
Than saide Gamelyn to the Iustice
Now is thy power don thow most nedes ryse
Thow hast yeuen domes that ben euel dight
I wille sitten in thi sete and dressen hem aright
The Iustice satte stille and roos not anoon
And Gamelyn cleued his cheke bon
Gamelyn toke hym in his armes and nomore spak
But threwe hym ouer the barre and his arme brak
Durst noon to Gamelyn say but good
For fere of the companye that with oute stode
Gamelyn sette hym doun in the Iustice stede
And sire Otes his broþer by hel and adam at his feet
Whan Gamelyn was sette in the Iustices sete
Herkeneth of borde that Gamelyn the dede
He lete fetere the Iustice and his fals brother
And lete hem come to the barre the toon with that other
Tho Gamelyn hadde thus I doo thoo had he no rest
Til he hadde enquered who was on the quest
Forto demen his brother ser Ote forto honge
Er he wist whiche they were it thought hym ful longe
But as sone as Gamelyn wyst where they were
He dide hem euer ychou fetere in fere
And bryngen hem to the barre and sette hem in rewe
By my faith saide the Iustice the shiref is a sherewe
Than saide Gamelyn to the Iustice
Thow haste yove domes of the worst assise
And thoo twelue sisours that weren of the quest
They shol ben honged to day so god yeue me good rest
Than saide the shiref to yonge Gamelyn
Lorde I crie the mercy brother art thow myn
Therfore saide Gamelyn haue thow cristis curs
For and thow were maister yet shold I fare wurs
For to make short tale and not to longe
He ordeyned hym a quest of his men so stronge
The Iustice and the shiref bothe honged hye
To wemen with the rapes and with the wynd drye
And the xij seisours sorow haue that rekke
Alle they were hanged fast by the nekke
Thus endeth the fals knyght with his trecherie
That euer had lad his lyfe in falsnesse and in folie
He was honged by the necke and not by the purs
That was the mede that he hadde for his faders curs
ser Ote was eldest and Gamelyn was yynge
Wenten with her frendes and passed with the kynge
They made pees with the kyng of the best sise
The kynge loued ser Ote wele and made hym Iustice
And after the kyng made Gamelyn both in Este and West
Chief Iustice of his free Forest
Alle his wight yonge men the kyng forgaf hire gilt
And sithen in good office the kyng had alle hym pilt
Thus wanne Gamelyn his londe and his lede
And wraked hym of his enemyes and quitte hem her mede
And ser Ote his brother made hym his aire
And sithen wedded Gamelyn a wyf good and faire
They lyueden to gider while that criste wolde
And sithen was Gamelyn grauen vnder molde
And so shal we alle may there noman flee
God brynge vs to the Ioye that euer shal be

Ovre hoost saw wel that the brighte sonne
The ark of his artificial day hath ronne
The ferthe part and half an hour and moore
And thogh he were nat depe ystert in loore
He wiste it was the eightene the day
Of April / that is messager to May
And saw wel / that the shadwe of euery tree
Was as in lengthe / the same quantitee
That was the body erect that caused it
And therfore by the shadwe / he took his wit
That Phebus / which that shoon so cleer and brighte
Degrees was fourty fyue clombe on highte
And for that day / as in that latitude
It was ten at the Clokke he gan conclude
And sodeynly / he plighte his hors aboute
¶ Lordynges quod he I warne yow al this route
The ferthe party of this day is goon
Now for the loue of god / and of Seint Iohn
Leseth no tyme / as ferforth as ye may
Lordynges the tyme / it wasteth nyght and day
And steleth from vs / what pryuely slepynge
And what thurgh necligence / in oure wakynge
As dooth the streem that turneth neuere agayn
Descendynge fro the montaigne in to playn
Wel kan Senec and many a Philosophre
Biwaillen tyme / moore than gold in cofre
For los of catel may recouered be
But los of tyme shendeth vs quod he
It wol nat come agayn / withouten drede
Namoore / than wol Malkyns maydenhede
Whan she hath lost it / in hir wantownesse
Lat vs nat / mowlen thus in ydelnesse
¶ Sire man of lawe quod he / so haue ye blys
Tel vs a tale anon / as forward is
Ye been submitted / thurgh youre free assent
To stonden in this cas / at my Iuggement
Aquiteth yow now / of youre biheste
Thanne haue ye doon youre deuoir atte leeste
¶ Hoost quod he depardieux ich assente
To breken forward / is nat myn entente
Biheste is dette / and I wol holde fayn
Al my biheste / I kan no bettre sayn
Plese yow / and therto wole I do my payne
For swich lawe / as a man yeueth another wight /
He sholde hymself / vsen it by right
Thus wol oure text / but nathelees certein
I kan right now / no thrifty tale seyn
That Chaucer / thogh he kan but lewedly
On metres / and on rymyng craftily
Hath seyd hem / in swich englissh as he kan
Of olde tyme / as knoweth many a man
And if he ne haue nat seyd hem / leeue brother
In o book he hath seyd hem in another
For he hath toold / of louers vp and doun
Mo than Ouide / made of mencioun
In his epistles / that been ful olde
What sholde I tellen hem / syn they been tolde
In yowthe he made / of Ceys and Alcione
And sithen hath he spoke of euerychone
Thise noble wyues / and thise loueres eke
Who so that wole / his large volum seke
Clepyd the Seintes legende of Cupide
Ther maystow seen /. the large woundes wyde
Of Lucresse / and of Babilan Tisbee
The swerd of Dido / for the false Enee
The tree of Phillis / for hir Demophon
The pleinte of Dianire / and of Hermyoun
Of Adriane / and of ysiphilee
The barayne Ile / stondynge in the See
The dreynte leandre / for his Erro
The terys of Eleyne / and eke the wo
Of Brixseyde / and of the Ladomea
The crueltee / of the queene Medea
The litel children / hangyng by the hals
For thy Iasoun / that was of loue so fals
O ypermystra / Penolopee / Alceste
Youre wifhod / he comendeth with the beste
But certeinly / no word ne writeth he
Of thilke wikke ensample / of Canacee
That loued / hir owene brother synfully
Of swiche cursed stories / I sey fy
Or ellis / of Tyro Appollonius
How that / the cursed kyng Antiochus
Birafte his doghter / of hir maydenhede
That is / so horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he hir threw / vpon the pauement
And therfore / he of ful auisement
Nolde neuere write / in noon of his sermons
Of swiche / vnkynde abhominacions
Ne I wol noon reherce / if that I may
But of my tale / how shal I doon this day
Me were looth / be likned doutelees
To Muses / that been clepyd Pierides
Methamorphosios / woot what I mene
But nathelees / I recche noght a bene
Thogh I come after hym / with hawe bake
I speke in prose / and lat hym rymes make
And with that word / he with a sobre cheere
Bigan his tale / as ye shal after heere

O hateful harm condicion of pouerte
With thurst with cold with hunger so confoundid
To axen help thee shameth in thyn herte
If thou noon axe with nede art thow so woundid
That verray nede vnwrappeth al thy wounde hid
Maugree thyn heed thou most for Indigence
Or stele or begge or borwe thy despence
Thou blamest Crist and seist ful bitterly
He mysdeparteth richesse temporal
Thy neghebore thow witest synfully
And seist thow hast to lite and he hath al
Parfay seistow som tyme he rekne shal
Whan that his tayl shal brennen in the gleede
For he noght helpeth nedefulle in hir nede
Herke what is the sentence of the wise
Bet is to dyen than haue Indigence
Thy selue neghebor wol thee despise
If thow be pouere fare wel thy reuerence
Yet of the wise man tak this sentence
Alle the dayes of pouere men been wikke
Be war therfore er thow come to that prikke
If thou be pouere thy brother hateth thee
And alle thy freendes fleen from thee allas
O riche Marchauntz ful of wele been ye
O noble o prudent folk as in this cas
Youre bagges been noght filled with ambes as
But with sys cynk that renneth for youre chaunce
At Cristemasse murye may ye daunce
Ye seken lond and see for youre wynnynges
As wise folk ye knowen al thestat
Of regnes ye been fadres of tidynges
And tales bothe of pees and of debat
I were right now of tales desolat
Nere that a Marchaunt goon is many a yere
Me taughte a tale which that ye shal heere
Heere bigynneth the man of lawe his tale
Incipit fabula
In Surrye whilom dwelte a compaignye
Of chapmen riche and ther to sadde and trewe
That wyde where senten hir Spicerye
Clothes of gold and Satyns riche of hewe
Hir cheffare was so thrifty and so newe
That euery wight hath deyntee to cheffare
With hem and eek to sellen hem hir ware
Now fil it that the maistres of that sort
Han shapen hem to Rome for to wende
Were it for chaphod or for desport
Noon oother message wolde they thider sende
But coomen hem self to Rome this is the ende
And in swich place as thoughte hem auauntage
For hir entente they take hir herbergage
Soiourned han thise Marchauntz in that town
A certein tyme as fil to hir plesaunce
But so bifel that the excellent renoun
Of the Emperours doghter dame Custaunce
Reported was with euery circumstaunce
Vnto thise Surryen Marchauntz in swich wise
Fro day to day as I shal yow deuyse
This was the commune voys of euery man
Oure Emperour of Rome god hym se
A doghter hath that syn the world bigan
To rekne as wel hir goodnesse as beautee
Nas neuere swich another as is she
I pray to god in honour hir sustene
And wolde she were of al Europe the queene
In hire is heigh beautee withoute pryde
Youthe withouten grenehede or folye
To alle hir werkes vertu is hir gyde
Humblesse hath slayn in hire al tirannye
She is Mirour of al curteisye
Hir herte is verray chambre of holynesse
Hir hand Ministre of fredam for almesse
And al this voys was sooth as god is trewe
But now to purpos lat vs come agayn
Thise Marchauntz han doon fraught hir shippes newe
And whan they han this blisful mayden sayn
Hom to Surrye been they went ful fayn
And doon hir nedes as they han doon yoore
And lyuen in wele I kan sey yow namoore
Now fil it that thise Marchauntz stode in grace
Of hym that was the Sowdan of Surrye
For whan they coome from any straunge place
He wolde of his benygne curteisye
Maken hem good cheere and bisily espye
Tidynges of sondry regnes for to leere
The wondres that they myghte seen or heere
Amonges othere thynges specially
Thise Marchauntz han hym told of dame Custaunce
So greet noblesse in ernest ceriously
That this Sowdan hath caught so greet plesaunce
To han hir figure in his remembraunce
And al his lust and al his bisy cure
Was for to loue hire whil his lyf may dure
Parauenture in thilke large book
Which that men clepe the heuene ywriten was
With sterres whan that he his birthe took
That he for loue sholde han his deth allas
For in the sterres clerer than is glas
Is writen god woot who so koude it rede
The deeth of euery man withouten drede
In sterres many a wynter ther biforn
Was writen the deeth of Ector Achilles
Of Pompei Iulius er they were born
The stryf of Thebes and of Hercules
Of Sampson Turnus and of Socrates
The deeth but mennes wittes been so dulle
That no wight kan wel rede it at theat the fulle
This Sowdan for his priuee conseil sente
And shortly of this matere for to pace
He hath to hem declared his entente
And seyde hem certein but he myghte haue grace
To han Custaunce with Inne a litel space
He nas but deed and charged hem in hye
To shapen for his lyf som remedye
Diuerse men diuerse thynges seyden
They argumenten casten vp and doun
Many a subtil reson forth they leyden
They speken of Magyk and abusioun
But finally as in conclusioun
They kan nat seen in that noon auauntage
Ne in noon oother wey saue mariage
Thanne sawe they ther Inne swich difficultee
By wey of reson for to speke al playn
By cause that ther was swich diuersitee
Bitwene hir bothe lawes that they sayn
They trowe that no cristen Prince wolde fayn
Wedden his child vnder oure lawes swete
That vs was taught by Mahoun oure prophete
And he answerde rather than I lese
Custaunce I wol be cristned doutelees
I moot ben hires I may noon oother chese
I pray yow hold youre argumentz in pees
Saueth my lyf and beth noght recchelees
To geten hire that hath my lyf in cure
For in this wo I may nat longe endure
What nedeth gretter dilatacioun
I seye by tretys and embassadrye
And by the Popes mediacioun
And al the chirche and al the chiualrie
That in destruccioun of Mawmetrie
And in encrees of Cristes lawe deere
They been acorded so as ye shal heere
How that the Sowdan and his Baronage
And alle his liges sholde ycristned be
And he shal han Custaunce in mariage
And certeyn gold I noot what quantitee
And heer to founden sufficient seuretee
This same acord was sworn on either syde
Now faire Custaunce almyghty god thee gyde
Now wolde som men waiten as I gesse
That I sholde tellen al the purueiaunce
That Themperour of his grete noblesse
Hath shapen for his doghter dame Custaunce
Wel may men knowen that so greet ordinaunce
May no man tellen in a litel clause
As was arrayed for so heigh a cause
Bisshopes been shapen with hire for to wende
Lordes ladies knyghtes of renoun
And oother folk ynowe this is thende
And notified is thurgh out the town
That euery wight with greet deuocioun
Sholde preyen crist that he this mariage
Receyue in gree and spede this viage
The day is comen of hir departynge
I seye the woful day fatal is come
That ther may be no lenger taryynge
I sey þe oful day fatel is comen
But forthward they hem dresse alle and some
Custaunce that was with sorwe al ouercome
Ful pale arist and dresseth hire to wende
For wel she seeth ther nys noon oother ende
Allas what wonder is it thogh she wepte
That shal be sent to straunge nacioun
Fro freendes that so tendrely hir kepte
And to be bounden vnder subieccioun
Of oon she knoweth noght his condicioun
Housbondes been alle goode and han been yoore
That knowen wyues I dar sey yow namoore
Fader she seyde thy wrecched child Custaunce
Thy yonge doghter fostred vp so softe
And ye my moder my souereyn plesaunce
That most you loueth with obeissaunce
Ouer alle thyng outtaken crist on lofte
Custaunce youre child hir recomaundeth ofte
Vnto youre grace for I shal to Surrye
Ne shal I neuere seen yow moore with eye
Allas vnto the Barbre nacioun
I moste anon syn that it is youre wille
But crist that starf for oure redempcioun
So yeue me grace hise hestes to fulfille
I wrecche womman no fors thogh I spille
Wommen are born to thraldom and penaunce
And to been vnder mannes gouernaunce
I trowe at Troye whan Pirrus brak the wal
Or Ylion brent hadde Thebes the Citee
Nat Rome for the harm thurgh Hanybal
That Romayns hath venquysshed tymes thre
Nas herd swich tendre wepyng for pitee
As in the chambre was for hir departynge
But forth she moot wher so she wepe or synge
O firste moeuer cruel firmament
With thy diurnal sweigh that crowdest ay
And hurlest al fro Est til Occident
That naturelly wolde holde another way
Thy crowdyng set the heuene in swich array
At bigynnyng of this fiers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayn this mariage
Infortunat Ascendent tortuous
Of which the lord is helplees falle allas
Out of his angle in to the derkest hous
O Mars O Atazir as in this cas
O fieble Moone vnhappy been thy pas
Thow knyttest thee ther thow nart nat receyued
Ther thow were wel fro thennes art thow weyued
Inprudent Emperour of Rome allas
Was ther no Philosophre in al thy town
Is no tyme bet than oother in swich cas
Of viage is ther noon eleccioun
Namely to folk of heigh condicioun
Nat whan a roote is of a burthe yknowe
Allas we been to lewed or to slowe
To ship is broght this woful faire mayde
Solempnely with euery circumstaunce
Now Ihu crist be with yow alle she seyde
Ther nys namoore but fare wel faire Custaunce
She peyneth hire to make good contenaunce
And forth I lete hir Sayle in this manere
And turne I wole agayn to my matere

The moder of the Sowdan welle of vices
Espied hath hir sones pleyn entente
How he wol lete his olde sacrifices
And right anon she for hir conseil sente
And they ben come to knowen what she mente
And whan assembled was this folk in feere
She sette hir down and seyde as ye shal heere
Lordes quod she ye knowen euerychon
How that my sone in point is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure Alkaron
Yeuen by goddes messagere Makomete
But oon avow to grete god I hete
The lyf shal rather out of my body sterte
Than Makometes lawe out of myn herte
What sholde vs tiden of this newe lawe
But thraldom to oure bodies and penaunce
And afterward in helle to be drawe
For we reneyed Mahoun oure creaunce
But lordes wol ye maken assuraunce
As I shal seyn assentyng to my loore
And I shal make vs sauf for euere moore
They sworen and assenten euery man
To lyue with hire and dye and by hir stonde
And euerich in the beste wise he kan
To strengthen hire shal alle hise freendes fonde
And she hath this emprise ytake on honde
Which ye shal heren that I shal deuyse
And to hem alle she spak right in this wise
We shul first feyne vs cristendom to take
Coold water shal nat greue vs but alite
And I shal swich a feste and reuel make
That as I trowe I shal the sowdan quyte
For thogh his wyf be cristned neuer so whyte
She shal haue nede to wasshe awey the rede
Thogh she a font ful water with hir lede
O Sowdanesse roote of Iniquitee
Virago thow Semyrame the secounde
O Serpent vnder femynynytee
Lyk to the Serpent depe in helle ybounde
O feyned womman al that may confounde
Vertu and Innocence thurgh thy malice
Is bred in thee as nest of euery vice
O Sathan enuyous syn thilke day
That thow were chaced from oure heritage
Wel knowestow to wommen the olde way
Thow madest Eua brynge vs in seruage
Thow wolt fordoon this cristen mariage
Thyn Instrument so weylawey the while
Makestow of wommen whan thou wolt bigile
This Sowdanesse whom I thus blame and warye
Leet pryuely hir conseil goon his way
What sholde I in this tale lenger tarye
She rideth to the Sowdan on a day
And seyde hym that she wolde reneye hir lay
And cristendom of preestes handes fonge
Repentynge hire she hethen was so longe
Bisekyng hym to doon hire that honour
That she moste han the cristen folk to feste
To plesen hem I shal do my labour
The sowdan seith I wol doon at youre heste
And knelynge thanketh hire of that requeste
So glad he was he nyste what to seye
She kiste hir sone and hom she gooth hir weye

Arryued been this cristen folk to londe
In Surrye with a gret solempne route
And hastily this Sowdan sente his sonde
First to his moder and al the regne aboute
And seyde his wyf was comen out of doute
And preyde hire for to ryde agayn the queene
The honour of his regne to sustene
Greet was the prees and riche was tharray
Of Surryens and Romayns met yfeere
The moder of the Sowdan riche and gay
Receyueth hire with also glad a cheere
As any moder myghte hir doghter deere
And to the nexte Citee ther bisyde
A softe paas solempnely they ryde
Naught trowe I the triumphe of Iulius
Of which that Lucan maketh swich a boost
Was roiallour ne moore curyus
Than was the assemblee of this blisful oost
But this scorpion this wikked goost
The Sowdanesse for al hir flaterynge
Caste vnder this ful mortally to stynge
The Sowdan cometh hymself soone after this
So roially that wonder is to telle
He welcometh hire with alle ioye and blys
And thus in myrthe and Ioye I lete hem dwelle
The fruyt of this matere is that I telle
Whan tyme cam men thoughte it for the beste
That reuel stynte and men go to hir reste
The tyme cam this olde Sowdanesse
Ordeyned hath this feste of which I tolde
And to the feste cristen folk hem dresse
In general ye bothe yonge and olde
Heer may men feste and roialtee biholde
And deyntees mo than I kan yow deuyse
But al to deere they boghte it er they ryse
O sodeyn wo that euere art Successour
To worldly blisse spreynd with bitternesse
The ende of the ioye of oure worldly labour
Wo ocupieth the fyn of oure gladnesse
Herke this conseil for thy sikernesse
Vpon thy glade day haue in thy mynde
The vnwar wo or harm that comth bihynde
For shortly for to tellen at a word
The Sowdan and the cristen euerychone
Been al to hewe and stiked at the bord
But it were oonly dame Custaunce allone
This olde sowdanesse cursed krone
Hath with hir freendes doon this cursed dede
For she hir self wolde al the contree lede
Ne ther nas Surryen noon that was conuerted
That of the conseil of the Sowdan woot
That he nas al tohewe er he asterted
And Custaunce han they take anon foot hoot
And in a Ship al sterelees god woot
They han hir set and bidde hir lerne sayle
Out of Surrye agaynward to Itaille
A certein tresor that she thider ladde
And sooth to seyn vitaille gret plentee
They han hir yeuen and clothes eek she hadde
And forth she sayleth in the salte see
O my Custaunce ful of benygnytee
O Emperours yonge doghter deere
He that is lord of Fortune be thy steere
She blisseth hire and with ful pitous voys
Vnto the cros of Crist thus seyde she
O clere o weleful Auter holy croys
Reed of the lambes blood ful of pitee
That wesshe the world fro the olde Iniquitee
Me fro the feend and fro his clawes kepe
That day that I shal drenchen in the depe
Victorious tree proteccion of trewe
That oonly worthy were for to bere
The kyng of heuene with his woundes newe
The white lamb that hurt was with a spere
Flemere of feendes out of hym and here
On which thy lymes feithfully extenden
Me kepe and yeue me myght my lyf tamenden
Yeres and dayes fleet this creature
Thurgh out the see of Grece vnto the Strayte
Of Marrok as it was hir auenture
O many a sory meel now may she bayte
After hir deth ful often may she wayte
Er that the wilde wawes wol hir dryue
Vnto the place ther she shal arryue
Men myghten axen why she was noght slayn
Eek at the feste who myghte hir body saue
And I answere to that demaunde agayn
Who saued Danyel in the horrible Caue
Ther euery wight saue he maister and knaue
Was with the leoun frete er he asterte
No wight but god that he bar in his herte
God liste to shewe his wonderful miracle
In hire for we sholde seen his myghty werkes
Crist which that is to euery harm triacle
By certein menes ofte as knowen clerkes
Dooth thyng for certein ende that ful derk is
To mannes wit that for oure ignoraunce
Ne konne noght knowe his prudent purueiaunce
Now sith she was nat at the feste yslawe
Who kepte hire fro the drenchyng in the See
Be north and south and also Este and weste
Who kepte Ionas in the fisshes mawe
Til he was spowted vp at Nynyuee
Wel may men knowe it was no wight but hee
That kepte peple Ebrayk from hir drenchyng
With drye feet thurgh out the See passyng
Who bad the foure Spiritz of tempest
That power han tanoyen lond and See
Bothe North and South and also West and Est
Anoyeth neither See ne land ne tree
Soothly the comaundour of that was hee
That fro the tempest ay this womman kepte
As wel whan she wook as whan she slepte
Wher myghte this wommam mete and drynke haue
Thre yeer and moore how lasteth hir vitaille
Who fedde the Egipcien Marie in the Caue
Or in desert no wight but crist sanz faille
Fyue thousand folk it was as greet meruaille
With loues fyue and fisshes two to fede
God sente his foyson at hir grete nede
She dryueth forth in to oure Occian
Thurgh out the wilde see til at the laste
Vnder an hoold that nempnen I ne kan
Fer in Northumberland the wawe hir caste
And in the sond hir ship stiked so faste
That thennes wolde it noght of al a tyde
The wyl of crist was that she sholde abyde
The Constable of the Castel down is fare
To seen this wrak and al the Ship he soghte
And foond this wery womman ful of care
He foond also the tresor that she broghte
In hir langage mercy she bisoghte
The lyf out of hir body for to twynne
Hir to deliuere of wo that she was Inne
A manere latyn corrupt was hir speche
But algates ther by was she vnderstonde
The Constable whan hym liste no lenger seche
This woful womman broghte he to the londe
She kneleth doun and thanketh goddes sonde
But what she was she wolde no man seye
For foul ne fair thogh that she sholde deye
