This mayde bright Cecilie as hir lyf seith
Was come of Romayns and of noble kynde
And from hir Cradel vp fostred in the feith
Of crist and baar his gospel in hir mynde
She neuere cessed as I writen fynde
Of hir prayere and god to loue and drede
Bisekyng hym to kepe hir maydenhede
And whan this mayden sholde vn til a man
Ywedded be that was ful yong of age
Which that ycleped was Valerian
And day was comen of hir mariage
She ful deuout and humble in hir corage
Vnder hir robe of gold that sat ful faire
Hadde next hir flessh yclad hire in an haire
And whil that the Organs maden melodie
To god allone in hir herte thus soong she
O lord my soule and eek my body gye
Vnwemmed lest that I confounded be
And for his loue that deyde vpon the tree
Euery seconde and thridde day she faste
Ay biddyng in hir orisons ful faste
The nyght cam and to bedde moste she gon
With hire housbonde as ofte is the manere
And priuely to hym she seyde anon
O swete and wel biloued spouse deere
Ther is a conseil and ye wolde it heere
Which that right fayn I wolde vnto yow seye
So that ye swere ye shul it nat biwreye
Valerian gan faste vnto hir swere
That for no cas ne thyng that myghte be
He sholde neuere mo biwreyen here
And thanne at erst to hym seyde she
I haue an Aungel which that loueth me
That with gret loue wher so I wake or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
And if that he may feelen out of drede
That ye me touche or loue in vileynye
He right anon wol sleen yow with the dede
And in youre youthe thus ye shullen dye
And if that ye in clene loue me gye
He wol yow loue as me for youre clennesse
And shewe to yow his ioye and his brightnesse
This Valerian corrected as god wolde
Answerde agayn if I shal trusten thee
Lat me that Aungel seen and hym biholde
And if that it a verray Aungel be
Thanne wol I doon as thow hast prayed me
And if thow loue another man for sothe
Right with this swerd than wol I sle yow bothe
Cecile answerde right in this wise
If that yow list the Aungel shal ye se
So that ye trowe on crist and yow baptise
Goth forth to Via Apia quod she
That fro this town ne stant but Milys thre
And to the poure folkes that ther dwellen
Sey hem right thus as that I shal yow tellen
Telle hem that I Cecile yow to hem sente
To shewen yow the goode Vrban the olde
For secree nedes and for good entente
And whan that ye Seint Vrban han biholde
Telle hym the wordes whiche I to yow tolde
And whan that he hath purged yow fro synne
Thanne shal ye seen that Aungel er we twynne
This Valerian is to the place gon
And right as hym was taught by his lernynge
He foond this holy olde Vrban anon
Among the Seintes buryels lotynge
And he anon withouten tariynge
Dide his message and whan that he it tolde
Vrban for ioye hise handes gan vp holde
The teerys from hise eyen leet he falle
Almyghty lord o Ihu crist quod he
Sowere of chaast conseil hierde of vs alle
The fruyt of thilke seed of chastitee
That thow hast sowe in Cecilie taak to thee
Lo lyk a bisy bee withouten gyle
Thee serueth ay thyn owene thral Cecile
For thilke spouse that she tok but now
Ful lyk a fiers leoun she sendeth heere
As meke as euere was any lamb to yow
And with that word anon ther gan appeere
An old man clad in white clothes cleere
That hadde a book with lettre of gold in honde
And gan biforn Valerian to stonde
Valerian as deed fil doun for drede
Whan he hym say and he vp hente hym tho
Whan he this old man sawe standing so
And on his book right thus he gan to rede
Whiche forthwith anone he herd hym rede
O lord o feith o god withoute mo
Et lamentat
O cristendom and fader of all also
Abouen alle and oueral euery where
Thise wordes al with gold ywriten were
Whan this was rad thanne seyde this olde man
Leuestow this thyng or no sey ye or nay
I leue al this thyng quod Valerian
I leeue all þis þing þan þis I dar wel say
For sother thyng than this I dar wel say
Vnder the heuene no wight thynke may
Tho vanysshed this olde man he nyste where
And pope Vrban hym cristned right there
Valerian goth hom and fynt Cecilie
In with his chambre with an Aungel stonde
This Aungel hadde of Roses and of lilie
Corones two the whiche he bar in honde
And first to Cecile as I vnderstonde
He yaf that oon and after gan he take
That oother to Valerian hir make
With body clene and with vnwemmed thoght
Kepeth ay wel thise corones quod he
Fro Paradys to yow haue I hem broght
Ne neuere mo ne shal they roten be
Ne lese hir swote sauour trusteth me
Ne neuere wight shal seen hem with his eye
But he be chaast and hate vileynye
And thow Valerian for thow so soone
Assentedest to good conseil also
Sey what thee list and thow shalt han thy boone
I haue a brother quod Valerian tho
That in this world I loue no man so
I pray yow that my brother may han grace
To knowe the trouthe as I do in this place
The Aungel seyde god liketh thy requeste
And bothe with the palm of martirdom
Ye shullen come vnto his blisful feste
And with that word Tiburce his brother coom
And whan that he the sauour vndernoom
Which that the Roses and the lilies caste
With Inne his herte he gan to wondre faste
He spak vnto his brother in gret haste
And seyde I wondre this tyme of the yere
Whennes that swote sauour cometh so
Of Rose and lilies that I smelle heere
For thogh I hadde hem in myne handes two
The sauour myghte in me no depper go
The swete smel that in myn herte I fynde
Hath chaunged me al in another kynde
Valerian seyde two corones han we
Snow white and Rose reed that shynen clere
Which that thyne eyen han no myght to se
And as thow smellest hem thurgh my prayere
So shaltow seen hem leue brother deere
If it so be thow wolt withouten slouthe
Bileue aright and knowen verray trouthe
Tiburce answerde seystow this to me
In soothnesse or in dreem I herkne this
In dremes quod Valerian han we be
Vnto this tyme brother myn ywys
And now at erst in trouthe oure dwellyng is
How wostow this quod Tiburce in what wyse
Quod Valerian that shal I thee deuyse
Telle me anon here with gode auyse
The Aungel of god hath me the trouthe ytaught
Which thow shalt seen if that thow wolt reneye
The ydoles and be clene and ellis nAught
And of the myracle of thise corones tweye
Seint Ambrose in his preface list to seye
Solempnely this noble doctour deere
Commendeth it and seith in this manere
The palme of martirdom for to receyue
Seinte Cecile fulfild of goddes yifte
The world and eek hir chambre gan she weyue
Witnesse Tiburces and Cecilies shrifte
To whiche god of his bountee wolde shifte
Corones two of floures wel smellynge
And made his Aungel hem the corones brynge
The mayde hath broght men to blisse aboue
The world hath wist what it is worth certeyn
Deuocion of chastitee to loue
Tho shewed hym Cecile al open and pleyn
That alle ydoles nys but a thyng in veyn
For they been dowmbe and ther to they been deue
And charged hym hise ydoles for to leue
Who so that troweth nat this a beest he is
Quod tho Tiburce if that I shal nat lye
And she gan kisse his brest that herde this
And was ful glad he koude trouthe espye
This day I take thee for myn allye
Seyde this blisful faire mayde deere
And after that she seyde as ye may heere
Lo right so as the loue of Crist quod she
Made me thy brotheres wyf right in that wise
Anon for myn allie heere take I thee
Syn that thow wolt thyne ydoles despise
Go with thy brother now and thee baptise
And make thee clene so that thow mowe biholde
The Aungeles face of which thy brother tolde
Tiburce answerde and seyde brother deere
First tel me whider that I shal and to what man
To whom quod he com forth with right good cheere
I wol thee lede vnto the pope Vrban
Til Vrban brother myn Valerian
Quod tho Tiburce woltow me thider lede
Me thynketh that it were a wonder dede
Ne menestow nat Vrban quod he tho
That is so ofte dampned to be deed
And woneth in halkes alwey to and fro
And dar nat ones putte forth his heed
Men sholde hym brennen in a fyr so reed
If he were founde or that men myghte hym spye
And we also to bere hym compaignye
And whil we seken thilke diuinytee
That is yhyd in heuene priuely
Algate ybrend in this world shul we be
To whom Cecile answerde boldely
Men myghten dreden wel and skilfully
This lyf to lese myn owene deere brother
If thys were lyuyng oonly and noon oother
But ther is bettre lyf in oother place
That neuere shal be lost ne drede thee noght
Which goddes sone vs tolde thurgh his grace
That fadres sone hath alle thynges wroght
And al that wroght is with a skilful thoght
The goost that fro the fader gan procede
Hath souled hem withouten any drede
By word and by myracle he goddes sone
Whan he was in this world declared heere
That ther was oother lyf ther men may wone
To whom answerde Tiburce o suster deere
Ne seydestow right now in this manere
Ther nys but o god lord in sothfastnesse
And now of thre how maystow bere witnesse
That shal I telle quod she er I go
Right as a man hath Sapiences thre
Memorie engyn and intellect also
So in o beynge of diuinytee
Thre persones may ther right wel be
Tho gan she hym ful bisily to preche
Of cristes come and of his peynes teche
And manye pointes of his passioun
How goddes sone in this world was withholde
To doon mankynde pleyn remyssioun
That was ybounde in synne and cares colde
Al this thyng she vnto Tiburce tolde
And after this Tiburce in good entente
With Valerian to Pope Vrban he wente
That thanked god and with glad herte and light
He cristned hym and made hym in that place
Parfit in his lernyng goddes knyght
And after this Tiburce gat swich grace
That euery day he say in tyme and space
The Aungel of god and euery maner boone
That he god axed it was sped ful soone
It were ful hard by ordre for to seyn
How many wondres Ihesus for hem wroghte
But at the laste to tellen short and pleyn
The sergeantz of the town of Rome hem soghte
And hem biforn Almache the Prefect broghte
Which hem opposed and knew al hir entente
And to the ymage of Iubiter hem sente
And seyde who so wol nat sacrifise
Swap of his heed this is my sentence heer
Anon thise martirs that I yow deuyse
Oon Maximus that was an Officer
Of the Prefectes and his Corniculer
Hem hente and whan he forth the Seintes ladde
Hymself he weep for pitee that he hadde
Whan Maximus hadde herd the Seintes loore
He gat hym of the tormentours leue
And ladde hem to his hous withoute moore
And with hir prechyng er that it were eue
They gonnen fro the tormentours to reue
And fro Maxime and fro his folk echone
The false feith to trowe in god allone
Cecile cam whan it was woxen nyght
With preestes that hem cristned alle yfeere
And afterward whan day was woxen light
Cecile hym seyde with a ful stedefast cheere
Now cristes owene knyghtes leue and deere
Cast al awey the werkes of derknesse
And armeth yow in armure of brightnesse
Ye han for sothe ydoon a greet bataille
Youre cours is doon youre feith han ye conserued
Goth to the corone of lyf that may nat faille
The rightful Iuge which that ye han serued
Shal yeue it yow as ye han it disserued
And whan this thyng was seyd as I deuyse
Men ledde hem forth to doon the sacrifise
But whan they weren to the place broght
To tellen shortly the conclusioun
They nolde encense ne sacrifise right noght
But on hir knees they setten hem adoun
With humble herte and sad deuocioun
And losten bothe hir heuedes in the place
Hir soules wenten to the kyng of grace
This Maximus that say this thyng bityde
With pitous teerys tolde it anon right
That he hir soules saugh to heuene glyde
With Aungeles ful of cleernesse and of light
And with his word conuerted many a wight
For which Almachius dide hym so bete
With whippe of leed til he his lyf gan lete
Cecile hym took and buryed hym anon
By Tiburce and Valerian softely
With Inne hir buryyng place vnder the stoon
And after this Almachius hastily
Bad hise Ministres fecchen openly
Cecilie so that she myghte in his presence
Doon sacrifice and Iubiter encense
But they conuerted at hir wise loore
Wepten ful sore and yauen ful credence
Vnto hir word and cryden moore and moore
Crist goddes sone withouten difference
Is verray god this is al oure sentence
That hath so good a seruant hym to serue
This with o voys we trowen thogh we sterue
Almachius that herde of this doynge
Bad fecchen Cecilie that he myghte hir se
And alderfirst lo this was his axynge
What maner womman artow quod he
I am a gentil womman born quod she
I axe thee quod he thogh it the greue
Of thy religioun and of thy bileue
Ye han bigonne youre question folily
Quod she that wolden two answeres conclude
In o demande ye axed lewedly
Almachie answerde vnto that similitude
Of whennes comth thyn answeryng so rude
Of whennes quod she whan that she was freyned
Of conscience and of good feith vnfeyned
Almachius seyde ne takestow noon hede
Of my power and she answerde hym this
Youre myght quod she ful litel is to drede
For euery mortal mannes power nys
But lyk a bladdre ful of wynd ywys
For with a nedles point whan it is blowe
May al the boost of it be leyd ful lowe
Ful wrongfully bigonne thow quod he
And yet in wrong is al thy perseueraunce
Wostow nat how oure myghty princes free
Han thus comanded and maad ordinaunce
That euery cristen wight shal han penaunce
But if that he his cristendom withseye
And goon al quyt if he wol it reneye
Youre Prynces erren as youre nobleye dooth
Quod tho Cecile and with a wood sentence
Ye make vs gilty and is nat sooth
For ye that knowen wel oure Innocence
For as muche as we doon a reuerence
To crist and for we bere a cristen name
Ye putte on vs a cryme and eek a blame
But we that knowen thilke name so
For vertuous we may it nat withseye
Almache answerde chees oon of thise two
Do sacrifice or cristendom reneye
That thow mowe now escapen by that weye
At which this holy blisful faire mayde
Gan for to laughe and to the Iuge she sayde
O Iuge confus in thy nycetee
Wiltow that I reneye Innocence
To maken me a wikked wight quod she
Lo he dissimuleth heere in audience
He stareth and woodeth in his aduertence
To whom Almachius vnsely wrecche
Ne wostow nat how fer my myght may strecche
Han noght oure myghty princes to me yeuen
Ye bothe power and auctoritee
To maken folk to dyen or to lyuen
Why spekestow so prowdly thanne to me
I speke noght but stedefastly quod she
Nat proudly for I seye as for my syde
We haten dedly thilke vice of pryde
And if thow drede nat a sooth to here
Thanne wol I shewe al openly by right
That thow hast maad a ful greet lesyng here
Thow seist thy princes han thee yeuen myght
Bothe for to sleen and for to quyken a wight
Thow that ne mayst but oonly lyf byreue
Boþe for to sleen and for to quyke a wight
Thow hast noon oother power ne no leue
But thow mayst seyn thy princes han thee maked
Ministre of deeth for if thow speke of me
Thow lyest for thy power is ful naked
Do wey thy boldnesse seyde Almachius tho
And sacrifice to oure goddes er thow go
I recche nat what wrong that thow me profre
For I kan suffre it as a Philosophre
But thilke wronges may I nat endure
That thow spekest of oure goddes here quod he
Cecilie answerde o nyce creature
Thow seydest no word syn thow spak to me
That I ne knew therwith thy nycetee
And that thow were in euery maner wise
A lewed Officer a veyn Iustise
Ther lakketh no thyng to thyne outter eyen
That thow nart blynd for thyng that we seen alle
That is a stoon that men may wel espien
That ilke stoon a god thow wolt it calle
I rede thee lat thyn hand vpon it falle
And taste it wel and stoon thow shalt it fynde
Syn that thow seest nat with thyne eyen blynde
It is a shame that the peple shal
So scornen thee and laughe at thy folye
For comenly men woot it wel oueral
That myghty god is in hise heuenes hye
And thise ymages wel thow mayst espye
To thee ne to hem self mowe noght profite
For in effect they be nat worth a myte
Thise and swiche othere seyde she
And he weex wrooth and bad men sholde hir lede
Hoom til hir hous and in hir hous quod he
Bren hire right in a Bath of flambes rede
And as he bad right so was doon the dede
For in a Bath they gonne hire faste shetten
And nyght and day greet fyr they vnder betten
The longe nyght and eek a day also
For al the fyr and eek the Bathes hete
She sat al coold and feeled no wo
It made hir nat o drope for to swete
But in that Bath hir lyf she moste lete
For he Almachius with a ful wikke entente
To sleen hire in the Bath his sonde sente
Thre strokes in the nekke he smoot hire tho
The tormentour but for no maner chaunce
He myghte noght smyte al hir nekke atwo
And for ther was that tyme an ordinaunce
That no man sholde doon man swich penaunce
The ferthe strook to smyten softe or soore
This tormentour ne dorste do namoore
But half deed with hir nekke ycoruen there
He lefte hir lye and on his wey he went
The cristen folk whiche that aboute hire were
With shetes han the blood ful faire yhent
Thre dayes lyued she in this torment
And neuere cessed hem the feith to teche
That she hadde fostred hem she gan to preche
And hem she yaf hir moebles and hir thyng
And to the Pope Vrban bitook hem tho
And seyde I axed this of heuene kyng
To han respit thre dayes and namo
To recommende to yow er that I go
To perfourme that I before haue do
Thise soules lo and that I myghte do Werche
Here of myn hous perpetuelly a cherche
Seint Vrban with hise deknes pryuely
The body fette and buryed it by nyghte
Among hise othere Seintes honestly
Hir hous the chirche of Seinte Cecilie highte
Seint Vrban halwed it as he wel myghte
In which in to this day in noble wyse
Men doon to crist and to his Seinte seruyse
Here is ended the Nonnes tale
¶ hic incipit fabula
Whan ended was the lyf of seint Cecile
Er we fully hadde ryden fyue myle
At Boghtoun vnder the blee . vs gan atake /
A man that clothed was in clothes blake
And vnder that he hadde a whit surplys
His hakeney that was al pomel grys
So swette that it wonder was to see
It semed he hadde priked myles thre
The hors eek that his ȝoman rood vpon
So swette that vnnethe mighte he gon
Aboute the pey fom ful hye
He was of foom al flekked as a pye
Aboute the peytrel stood the foom ful hiȝe
He was of fome al flekked as a pye
A male twyfold on his croper lay
It semed that he caryed lytel aray
Al light for somer rood this worthy man
And in myn herte wondren I bygan
What that he was til that I vnderstood
How that his cloke was sewed to his hood
For which whan I longe hadde avised me /
I demed him som chanoun for to be /
His hat hyng at his bak doun by a las /
For he hadde ryde more than trot or pas /
He hadde ay priked lyk as he were wood
A clote leef he hadde vnder his hood
For swot and for to kepe his heed from hete
But it was ioye for to seen him swete /
His forhed dropped as a stillatorie
Were ful of plaunteyne and of peritorie
And whan that he cam he bigan to crye
God saue quod he this Ioly companye
Faste haue I priked quod he for ȝoure sake
Ful faste you to ouertake
By cause that I wolde ȝou ouertake /
But yit I pray the for goddis sake
To ryden in this merye companye
His ȝoman eek was ful of curtesye
And sires now in the morwe tyde /
Out of ȝoure ostellerye I sayz ȝou ryde
And warned heer my lord and my souerayn
Which that to ryde with ȝou is ful fayn
For his disport he loueth daliaunce
Frend for thy warnyng god ȝiue the good chaunce
Sayde oure oost certes it wolde seeme /
Thy lord were wys and so I may wel deme
He is ful iocunde also dar I lay
Kan he ought telle a merye tale or tway
With which he glade may this companye
Who sire my lord ; ȝe ȝe withoute lye /
He can of merthe and eek of Iolite
Nought but ynough also sire trusteth to me
And ȝe him knewe als wel as do I
Ȝe wolde wondre how wel and thriftyly
He couthe werke and that in sondry wyse
He hath take on him many sondry aprise
Which were ful hard for eny that is heere /
To bringe aboute but they of him it lere
As homely as he ryt amonges ȝou
If ȝe him knewe it wolde be ȝoure prow /
Ȝe nolde not forgon his aqueintance
For mochil good I dar leye in balaunce
Al that I haue my possessioun
He is a man of heigh discrecioun
I warne ȝou wel he is a passynge man
Wel quoth oure host I pray the telle me than
Is he a Clerk or noon tell what he is
Nay he is gretter than a clerk y wys
Seyde the ȝoman and in wordes fewe
Oft and of his craft somwhat I wol ȝou schewe
I say my lord can such a sotilte
But all his crafte ȝe may not wite at me
And somwhat helpe I ȝit to his worchinge
That al this ground which that we ben on rydynge
Til that we come to Caunturbury toun
For al the ground to Caunturbury toun
He couthe al clene turne it vp se doun
And paue it al of siluer and of gold
And whan this ȝoman hadde thus y told
Vnto oure //hoost he seyde benedicite
This thing is wonder merueylous to me /
Sithens that thi lord is of so heigh prudence /
By cause of which men scholde him reuerence /
That of his worschipe rekketh he so lyte
His ouer sloppe nys nouȝt worth a myte /
As in effecte to him so mote I go
It is al baudy and to tore also
Whi is thi lord so sluttissche I the prey
And is of power better clothes to bey
If that his dede acorde with thy speche
Tell me that and that I the byseche /
Why quod this ȝeman wherto aske ȝe me /
God help me so for he schal neuer y the
But I wol not avowe that I say
And therfore kepe it secre I ȝou pray
He is to wys in faith as I bileeue
And that is ouer doon it nyl not preue
And right as clerkes sein it is a vice
Wherfore in that I holde him lewed and nyce
For whan a ma hath ouer gret a witt
Ful often it happeth to mysvsen it
So doth my lord and that me greueth sore
God it amende I can seye now no more
Ther of no fors goode ȝoman quod oure hoost
Sithens of the connyng of thy lord thou woost
Tell how he doth I pray the hertely
Sithens that he is so crafty and so sly
Wher dwellen ȝe if to telle be
In subarbes of a toun quod he
Lurkyng in hernes and in lanes blynde
Where thise Robbers and theeues be kynde
Holden here preuy ferful resydence
As thay that dur nat schewe here presence
So fare we if I schal saye the sothe
Ȝit quod oure hoste lat me talke tothe
Why art thou discoloured on thy face
Peter quod he god ȝiue hit harde grace
I am so vsed in the fyre to blowe
That it hath chaunged my colour as I trowe
I nam nat wont in myrour to prye
But swynke sore and lerne to multiplye
We bloundren euer and pouren in the fyr
And for al that we faillen of oure desir
For euer we lacken oure conclusioun
To moche folk we ben but Illusioun
And borwe gold be it a pound or tuo
Or ten or twelue or manye sommes mo
And make hem wenen atte leste weye
That of a pound we couthe make tweye
Ȝit is it fals and ay we han good hope
It for to don and after it we grope
But that science is so fer vs biforn
We mowe not although we hadde it sworn
It ouertake it slyt awey so faste
It wole us make beggeres atte laste
Whil this ȝoman was thus in this talking
This chanoun drough him ner and herde all thing
Which that this ȝoman spak for suspecioun
Of mennes speche euere hadde this Chanoun
For Catoun seith he that gulty is
Demeth all thing be spoke of him ywys
By cause of that he gan so neigh to drawe /
His ȝoman that he herde all his sawe /
And thus he sayde vnto his ȝoman tho
Holde now thy pees and speke wordes no mo /
For if thou dost thou schalt it dere abye
Thou sclaundrest me here in this compaignye
And eek discouerest that thou scholdest hyde
Ȝee quod oure hoost / telle on what so betyde
Of all this thretyng recche I nat a myte
I faith quod he no more do I but a lite
And whan this Chanoun say it wolde nat be
But his ȝoman wolde telle his priuyte
He fledde awey for verray sorwe and schame /
A quod the ȝoman here schal aryse a game
Al that I can anon right wol I telle
Sithens he is gon the foule feend him quelle /
For neuer her after wol I with him mete
For peny ne for pound I ȝou biheete /
He that me broughte ferst vnto that game /
Er that he deye sorwe haue he and schame
For it is ernest to me by my fayth
That feele I wel what so eny man saith /
So shal he finde for sothe that it assaieth
And ȝit for al my smert and al my greef
For al my sorwe labour and mescheef
I couthe neuer leue it in no wyse
Now wolde god my witt mighte suffise
To tellen al that longeth to that art
But napeles ȝit wol I telle a part
Sythens that my lord is gon I wol not spare
Such thing as I knowe I wol declare /
¶ Heere endeþ þe prologe of the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
With this chanoun dwelled haue I seuen ȝeer
And of his science am I neuer the neer
Al that I hadde I haue y lost therby
And god wot so haue many mo than I
Ther I was wont to be right freissch and gay
Of clothing and of good array
Now may I were an hose vpon myn heed
And wher my colour was bothe freissh and reed
Now is it wan and of a ledene hewe
Who so it vseth sore schal he rewe
And of my swynk ȝit blered is myn yȝe
Lo which auauntage it is to multiplye
That slydynge science hath me maad so bare
That I haue no good where that euer I fare
And ȝit I am endetted so ther by
Of gold that I haue borwed trewely
That whil I lyue I schal it quite neuere /
Lat euery man be war by me for euere /
What maner man that casteth him therto
If he continue I holde his thrifte y do
So help me god ther by schal he not wynne
But empte his purs and make his wittes thinne
And whan he thorugh his madnesse and folye
Hath lost his owne good thorugh Iepardye
Thanne he exciteth other folk therto
To lese here good as himself hath do
For vnto schrewes Ioye it is and ese
To haue here felawes in peyne and disese
Thus was I ones lerned of a clerk
Of that no charge I wol speke of oure werk
Whan we ben there as we schulle exercise
Oure eluysshe craft ; we semen wonder wise
Oure termes ben so clergeal and so queynte
I blowe the fuyr til that myn herte feynte
What scholde I telle eche proporcioun
Of thinges whiche that we worchen vppon
As on fyue or sixe vnces may wel be
Of siluer ore of som other quantite
And besye me to telle ȝou the names
Of Opyment brent bones yren squames
That in to poudre grounden ben ful smal
And in an erthen pot how that put is al
And salt y put in and also paupere
Bifore thise poudres that I speke of here
And wel y couered with a laumpe of glas
And of muche other thing what that ther was
And of the pot and glas englutyng
That of the aier mighte passe no thing
And of the esy fyr and smert also
Which that was mad and of the care and wo
That we hadde in oure matiers sublymynge
And amalgamynge and Calcenynge
Of quyk syluer y cleped mercurie crude
For all oure sleightes we can nouȝt conclude
Oure orpymed and sublimed mercurie
Oure grounde litarge eek on the porphirie
Of ech of thise of vnces a certayn
Nouȝt helpeth vs oure labour is in vain
Ne eek oure spirites ascensioun
Ne eek oure matieres that lyn al fixe a doun
Mowen in oure werkynge no thing vs auayle
For lost is all oure labour and trauaile
And al the cost on twenty deuele wey
Is lost also which we vpon it ley
Ther is also many another thing
That is to oure crafte aperteynyng
Though I by ordre hem here ne reherse can
By cause that I am a lewed man
Ȝit wol I telle hem as they come to mynde
Though I ne kan nat sette hem in here kynde
As boole armonyak verdegres Boras
And sondry vesseles made of erthe and glas
Oure vrinales and oure descensories
Violes creseletes and sublimatories
Concurbites and Alembykes eeke
And other swiche deere ynough a leeke
Nat needeth it to rehersen hem all
Wateres Rubysynge and boles galle
Arsynek Sal armonyak and Brymstoun
And herbes couthe I telle eek many oon
As Egrymoyne Valerian and lunarie
And other suche if that me luste tarie
Oure laumpes brennyng bothe night and day
To bringe aboute oure craft if that we may
Oure fornays eke of Calcynacioun
And of watres albyficacioun
Vnslekked lym chalk and glaire of an ey
Poudres dyers aisshes dong pisse and cley
Seryd pokettes Sal petre and vitriole
And diuerse fyres made of woode and cole
Salt tartre Alcaly and Salt preparat
And combust matieres and coagulat
Cley maad with horses or mannes heer and oyle
Of tartre alym glas berme wort and argoyle
Rysalgar and other matieres enbykynge
And eek of oure matieres encorporynge
And eek of Siluer Citrynacioun
Oure sementynge and fermentacioun
Oure Ingotes testes and many mo
I wol ȝou telle as was me taught also /
The foure spirites and the bodyes seuene /
By ordre ofte as I herde my lord neuene
The fyfte spirit quyk siluer called is
The seconde orpiment . the thridde y wys
Sal armoniak and the ferthe bremston
The bodyes seuene eek lo hem heere anon
Sol gold is and luna siluer we threpe
Mars yren mercurie quyk syluer we clepe
Saturnus leed and Iubiter is tyn
And venus Copur by my fader kyn
This cursede craft who so wol exercise
He schal no good han that may him suffise
For all the good he spendeth ther aboute
He lese schal ther of haue I no doute
Who so that list to outen his folye
Let him come forth and lerne to multiplie
And euery man that hath aught in his cofre
Lat him appere and wexe a philosophre
As scaunce that craft is so light for to lere
Nay nay god woot al be he monk or frere /
Preste or Chanoun or eny other wight
Though he sitte at his book bothe day and night
In lernyng of this eluyssh nyce lore /
Al is in veyn and parde moche more
Is to lerne a lewed man this sotilte
Fy speke nouȝt therof for it wol not be
Al cowde he letterure or couthe he non
As in effecte he schal fynde it al on
For bothe tuo by my saluacioun
Concluden in multiplicacioun
I liche wel whan they han all y do
This is to seyn they faille bothe tuo
Ȝit forȝat I to moche rehersaille
Of watres corosif and of lymaille
And of bodyes mollificacioun
And also of here induracioun
Oyles ablucioun and metall fusible
To tellen all wolde passen ony bible
That owher is wherfore as for the beste
Of all thise names now wole I me reste
For as I trowe I haue ȝou told ynough
To reysen a feende loke he neuer so rough
A nay let be thy philosophres ston
Elixir cleped we sechen faste echoon
For hadde we him than were we syker ynough
But vnto god of heuene I make avow
For all oure craft whan we han al y do
And al oure sleighte / he wol not come vs to
He hath vs maad spende moche good
For sorwe of which almost we wexen wood
But that good hope crepeth in oure herte
Supposyng euere though we sore smerte
To be releuyd by him aftirward
Supposyng and hope is scharp and hard
I warne ȝou wel it is to seken euere
That future temps hath maad men disseuere
In trust ther of fram al that euer they hadde
Ȝit of that art they couthe not wexe sadde
For vnto hem it is a bitterswete
So semeth it for ne hadde they but a scheete
Which that they mighte wrappe hem In a night
And a bak to walken in by day light
They wolde hem sellen and spenden on this craft
They can nouȝt stynte til no thing be laft
And euermore wher that euer they gon
Men may hem knowe by smel of Bremston
For al the world they stynken as a goot
Here sauour is so Rammissh and so hoot
That though a man from hem a myle be
That sauour wol enfecte him trusteth me
Lo thus by smellyng and by thred bare array
If that men list this folk they knowe may
And if a man wol aske him priuely
Why they ben clothed so vnthriftily
Right anon they wole rownen in his eere
And seye if thay aspyed were
Men wolde hem sle by cause of here science
Lo thus this folk bytrayen Innocence
Passe ouer this I go my tale vnto
Er then the pot be on the fyr y do
Of metals with a certein quantite
My lord hem tempreth and no man but he
Now he is gon I dar say boldely
For as men sein he can do craftily
Algate I wot wel he hath such a name
And ȝit ful ofte he renneth in the blame
And wite ȝe how ful ofte it happeth so
The pot tobreketh and far wel all is go
Thise metals ben of so gret violence
Oure walles may not make hem resistence
But if they were wrouȝt of lym and stoun
They percen so and thoruȝ the wal they goun
And some of hem synken in to the ground
Thus haue we lost by tymes many a pound
And somme are scatered al the floor aboute
Somme lepen in to the roof withouten doute
Though that the fende nought in oure sighte him schewe
I trowe that he with vs be that schrewe
In helle wher that he is lord and sire /
Ne is ther no more woo ne angur nor Ire
Whan that oure pot is broke as I haue sayd
Euery man chit and halt him yuel payd
Som seyde it was long on the fyr makyng
Somme sayde nay it was on the blowyng
Than was I fered for that was myn office
Straw quod the thridde ȝe ben lewed and nyce
It was not tempred as it oughte be /
Nay quod the ferthe stynt and herkne me
By cause oure fyr was nat made of bech
That is the cause non other so theech
I can not telle wher on it is a long
But wel I wot gret stryf is vs among
What quod my lord ther is nomore to done /
Of thise periles I wil be war eft sone /
I am right syker that the pot was crased
Be as be may be ȝe no thing amased
As vsage is let swope the floor as swythe
Pluk vp ȝour herte and be ȝe glad and blithe
The mullok on an heep y swoped was
And on the floor cast a kaneuas
And al this mullok in a Syue y throwe
And y sifted and y plucked many a throwe
Parde quod oon som what of oure metal
Ȝet is ther heere though we haue not all
And though this thing myshapped hath as now
Another tyme it may be wel ynow
Vs moste putte oure good in auenture /
A marchaunt parde may not ay endure
Trustneth me wel in his prosperite
Som tyme his good is drowned in the see /
And som tyme cometh it sauf vnto the londe
Pees quod my lord the nexte tyme I wol fonde
To bringe oure crafte all in another plyt
And but I do sires lat me haue the wyte
Ther was defaute in somwhat wel I woot
Another seyde the fyr was ouer hoot
But be it hoot or cold I dar seye this
That we concluden eueremore amys
We faille of that which that we wolde haue /
And in oure madnesse eueremore we raue
And whan we ben togidere euerich on
Euery man semeth as wys as Salomon
But all thing which that semeth as the goolde /
Is nat golde as I haue herd it tolde /
Ne euery appul that is fair at ye
Ne is not good what so men clappe or crye /
Right so lo fareth it amonges vs
He that semeth the wysest by Ihus
Is most fool whan it cometh to the preef
And he that semeth trewest is a theef
That schul ȝe knowe er that I fro ȝou wende /
By that I of my tale haue maad an ende
¶ Explicit pima pars / . Et sequitr pars secunda ~
Ther is a chanoun of Religioun
Amonges vs wolde enfecte al a toun
Though it as gret were as was Nynyue /
Rome Alisandre . Troye and othre thre
His sleightes and his infinite falsnesse /
Ther couthe noman writen as I gesse /
Though that he mighte lyuen a thousend ȝeer
In all this world of falnesse nys his peer
For in his termes he wole him so wynde /
And speke his wordes in so sleigh a kynde /
Whan he commune schal with ony wight
What he wol make him dote anon right
But it the feend be as his seluen is /
Ful many a man hath he begyled er this
And wile if that he may lyue a while /
And ȝit men ryden and gon ful many a myle
Him for to seeke and haue his aqueyntance
Nouȝt knowyng of his false gouernance /
And if ye lust to ȝiue me audience
I wol it tellen here in ȝoure presence
But worschipful Chanoun religious
Ne demeth nouȝt that I sclaundre ȝour hous
Although my tale of a Chanoun be
Of euery ordre som schrewe is parde
And god forbede that all a compaignie
Scholde rewe a synguler mannes folye
To sclaundre ȝou it is not myn entent
But to correcten that mys I ment
This tale nas nat oonly told for ȝou
But eek for other mo ȝe wot wel how
That amonges cristes apostles twelue
Ther was no traytour but Iudas himselue
Thanne why scholde the remenaunt all haue blame
That gulteles were by ȝou sey I the same
Sauf oonly this if ȝe wiln herkne me
If ony Iudas in ȝoure couent be
Remeneth him by tyme I ȝou rede
If schame or losse may causen ony drede
And beth no thing displesed I ȝou pray
¶ Narrat
But in this caas herkneth what I say
In londoun was a prest an annueler
That ther Inne dwelled hadde many a ȝeer
Which was so plesaunt and so seruisable /
Vnto the wyf wher he was at the table
That sche wolde suffre him no thing for to pay
For bord nor clothing wente he non so gay
And spendyng siluer had he right ynough
Ther of no force I wol procede as now /
Therof no force in plesaunce went his plow
And telle forth my tale of the Chanoun
That brouȝte this prest to confusioun
This false Chanoun cam vpon a day
Vnto the prestes chambre there he lay
Byseching him to lene him a certeyn
Of golde and he wold quite it him ageyn
Leneth me a mark quod he but dayes thre
And at my day I wol it quite the
And if so be that thou fynde me fals
Another day hang me vp by the hals
This prest him tok a mark and that as swithe
And this Chanoun him thanked often sithe
And took his leue and wente forth his wey
And atte thridde day brouȝt his money
And to this prest he took this gold agein
Ther of this prest was glad and fayn
Certes quod he no thing anoyeth me
To lene a man a noble or tuo or thre
Or what thing were in my possessioun
Whan he so trewe is of condicioun
That in no wise he breke wole his day
To swich a man I can neuer say nay
What quod this Chanoun scholde I be vntrewe
Nay that were thing fallen al of the newe
Trouthe is a thing that I wol euer kepe
Vnto the day in which that I schal crepe
In to my graue and elles god forbede
Bileeueth this as siker as is ȝoure Crede
God thanke I and in good tyme be it sayd
That ther was neuer man ȝit euel payd
For gold ne siluer that he to me lente
Ne neuere falshede in myn herte I mente
And sire quod he now of my priuyte
Sithens ȝe so goodlich haue ben to me
And kithed to me so gret gentilnesse
Somwhat to quite with ȝoure kyndenesse
I wol ȝou schewe and if ȝou lest to leere /
I schal it schewe to ȝou anon right heere
I wol yow teche / pleynly the manere
How I kan worchen in philosophie
Taketh good heed ȝe schuln seen wel at ye
That I wol don a maystry ar I go
Ȝe quoth the prest / ȝe sire and wil ȝe so
Marie ther of I pray ȝou hertily
At ȝoure comaundement sire trewely
Quoth the Chanoun and elles god forbede
Lo how this theef couthe his seruise beede
Ful soth it is that such profred seruise
Stynketh as witnessen thise olde wise
And that ful sone I wol it verefye
In this Chanoun is roote of alle treccherie
That eueremore delyt hath and gladnesse /
Suche feendly thoughtes in his herte impresse /
How cristes poeple he may to meschief bringe
God kepe vs from his fals dissimilynge
What wiste this prest with whom that he delte
Ne of his harm comynge no thing he felte
O sely prest o sely Innocent
With coueytise anon thou schalt be blent
O graceles ful blynd is thy conceyt
No thing artow war of the deceyt
Which that this fox y schapen hath to the /
His wyly wrenches thou mayst nouȝt fle
Wher fore to go to the conclusioun
That referreth to thi confusioun
Vnhappy man anon I wol me hiȝe
To telle thin vnwitte and thy folye
And eek the falsnesse of that other wrecche
As ferforth as my connynge wol strecche
This Chanoun was my lord ȝe wolde weene
Sire ofte in faith and by the heuen quene
It was another chanoun and nat he
That can an hundred fold more sotyltee
He hath bytrayed folkes many tyme
Of his falsnesse it dulleth me to Ryme
Euer whan I speke of his falshede
For schame of him my chekes wexen reede
Algates they bygynne for to glowe
For reednesse haue I now right wel I knowe
In my visage for fumes diuerse
Of metals whiche ȝe haue herd me reherce
Consumed and wasted han my reednesse /
Now take heede of this Chanouns cursednesse
Sire quod he to the prest lat ȝoure man gon
For quyk siluer that we it hadde anon
And lat him bringe vnces tuo or thre
And whan he cometh as faste schul ȝe see
A wonder thing which ȝe say neuer ar this
Sire quod the prest it schal ben don y wys
He bad his seruaunt fechen him his thing
And he al redy was at his biddyng
And wente him forth and cam anon agayn
With this quyk siluer schortly for to sayn
And tok this vnces thre to the Chanoun
And he it leyde faire and wel a doun
And bad the seruaunt coles for to bringe
That he anon mighte go to his worchinge
The coles right anon weren y fette
And this chanoun tok out a crosselette
Of his bosom and schewed it the prest
This Instrument quod he which that thou seest
Tak in thin hond and put thiself ther Inne
Of this quyk siluer an vnce and here bygynne
In the name of crist to wexe a Philosophre
Ther ben ful fewe which that I wolde profre
To schewen hem thus mochel of my science
For ȝe schuln seen heere by experience
That this quyk siluer I wol mortefye
Right in ȝoure sight anon withoute lye
And make it as good siluer and as fyn
As ther is ony in ȝoure purs or myn
Or elles where and make it malliable /
And elles holde me fals and vnable
Amonges folk euere to appere
I haue a poudre here that coste me deere
Schal make al good for it is cause of all
My connynge which that I ȝou schewe schall
Voydeth ȝoure man and lat him be theroute /
And schitte the dore whiles we ben aboute
Oure pryuyte that noman vs espie
Whiles we werken in this philosophie /
Al as he bad fulfilled was in dede /
This ilke seruaunt anon right out ȝede
And his maister schitte the dore anoun
And to here labour speedily they gon
This prest at this cursed chanouns byddyng
Vpon the fire anon sette this thing
And blew the fyr and busyed him ful faste
And this chanoun in to this Crosselet caste /
A poudre not I wher of that it was /
I maad other of chalk other of glas
Or som what elles was not worth a flye
To blynde with this prest and bad him hye
Thise coles for to couchen al aboue
The cresselet for in tokne that I the loue
Quoth this Chanoun thine hondes tuo
Shulle worche all thing which as schal be do
Graunt mercy quod the prest and was ful glad
And couchede coles as the Chanoun bad
And whils he besy was this feendly wrecche
This false Chanoun the foule feend him fecche
Out of his bosom took a bechene cole /
In which ful sotilly was maad an hole
And ther Inne put was of siluer lymaille
An vnce and stopped was withoute faille
This hole with wex to kepe the lymaille In
And understondeth that this false gyn
Was not made there but it was maad bifore
And othere thinges I schal telle more /
Here aftirward which that he with him broughte
Er he cam ther to begyle him he thoughte
And so he dide er they wente a twynne /
Til he had torned him couthe he not blynne
It dulleth me whan that I of him speke
On his falshede fayn wolde I me wreke
If I wiste how but he is heer and there /
He is so variaunt that he abyt no where /
But taketh heed now sires for goddes loue
He took his cole of which I spak aboue
And in his hond he bar it priuely
And whiles the prest couchide busily
The coles as I tolde ȝou er this /
This Chanoun sayde freend ȝe don amys
This is nought couched as it oughte be
But sone I schal amenden it quod he
Now lat me medle therwith but a while
For of ȝou haue I pite by seint Gyle
Ȝe ben right hoot I se wel how ȝe swete
Haue heere a cloth and wype awey the wete
And while that the prest him wyped has
This Chanoun took his cole I schrewe his fas
This Chanon toke his cole with sory grace
And leyde it vppon abouen the myddeward
Of the Crosselet and blew wel aftirward
Til that the coles gonne faste brenne
Now ȝif vs drinke quod the Chanoun thenne
As swithe it schal be wel I vndertake
Sitte we doun and let vs merie make
And whan the Chanouns bechene cole
Was brent all the lymail out of the hole
In to the Crosselet anon fel doun
And so it moste neede by resoun
Syns it so euene aboue couched was
But therof wiste no thing the prest allas
He demed all the coles liche goode
For of the sleight no thing he vnderstoode
And whan this alkamistre say his tyme
Riseth vp sire prest and stondeth byme
And for I wot wel Ingot haue ȝe non
Goth walketh forth and bring a chalk ston
For I wol make it of the same schappe
That is an Ingot if I may haue happe
And bring with ȝou a bolle other a panne
Ful of water and ȝe schul see thanne
How that oure busynesse schal happe and preeue
And ȝit for ȝe schul haue no mysbyleeue
Ne wrong conceyt of me in ȝoure absence
I wol not ben out of ȝoure presence
But go with ȝou and come with ȝou agayn
The chambre dore schortly for to sayn
They openyd and schette and wente forth here weye
And forth with hem they caryed the keye
And comen agayn withouten eny delay
What scholde I tarie al the longe day
He took the chalk and schoop it in the wyse
Of an yngot as I schal ȝou deuyse
I say he took out of his owne sleeue
A teyne of Siluer euele mote he cheeue
Which that was but an vnce of weight
And taketh heede now of his cursed sleight
He schop his Ingot in lengthe and in brede
Of the theyne withouten eny drede
So slyly that the prest it not aspyde
And in his sleeue again he gan it hyde
And from the fyre took vp his matiere /
And in to the Ingot it putte with merye cheere
And in to the watir vessel he it caste
Whan that him liste and bad the prest as faste
Loke what there is / put in thin hond and grope /
Thou schalt fynde there siluer as I hope
What deuel of helle sholde it elles be
Shauyng of siluer / siluer is parde
What deuyl of helle schuld it elles be
Schafyng of siluer siluer is parde
He putte in his hond and took vp a teyne
Of siluer fyn and glad in euery veyne
Was this prest whan he saugh that it was so
Goddes blessyng and his modres also
And all halwes haue ȝe sire Chanoun
Seyde the prest and .I. here malisoun
But and ȝe vouche sauf to teche me
This noble crafte and this sotilte
I wol be ȝoure in all that euer I may
Quoth the Chanoun ȝit wol I make assay
The seconde tyme that ȝe mowe take heede
And ben expert of this and in ȝoure neede
Another day in myn absence /
This discipline and this crafty science
¶ Let take another vnce quod he tho
Of quyk siluer withoute wordes mo
And do therwith as ȝe han don ar this
With that other which that now siluer is
This prest him busieth in al that he can
To don as this Chanoun this cursede man
Comaundeth him and faste blew the fire
For to come to theffecte of his desire
And this Chanoun right in the mene while
Al redy was this prest eft to begyle
And for a contynaunce in his hond bar
An holough stikke tak heede and be war
In the ende of which an vnce and no more
Of siluer lymaile put was al bifore
Was in his coole and stopped with wex wel
For to kepe in his lymayl euery del
And whiles this prest was in his businesse
This Chanoun with his stikke gan him dresse
To him anon and his poudre caste In
As he dede er the deuel out of his skyn
Him torne I pray to god for his falshede
For he was euer fals in othe and dede
And with his stikke aboue the crosselette
That was ordeigned with that false gette
He stereth the coles til it relente gan
The wax agayn the fyr as euery man
But it a fool be woot wel and moot neede
And al that in the hole was out ȝede
And in to the Crosselet hastily it fel
The prest supposede nothing but wel
¶ Now good sires what wol ye bet than wel
But busyed him faste and was wonder fayn
Whan þt this preest . thus was bigiled ageyn
Supposyng nouȝt but trouthe soth to sayn
He was so glad I can nouȝt expresse
In no maner his merthe and his gladnesse
And the chanoun he profred eft sone
Body and good ȝe quod the Chanoun soone
Though pore I be crafty thou schalt me fynde
I warne the ȝit is ther more behynde
Is ther eny coper here Inne seyde he
Ȝe sire quod the prest I trowe therbee
Elles go bey som and that as swithe
Now sire go forth thy way and hythe
And went his way and with this coper he cam
And this Chanoun in his hond it nam
And of that coper weyde out but an vnce
Al to symple is my tonge to pronounce
His moustre and his wit the doublenesse
As Mynystre of my witte . the doublenesse
Of this Chanoun roote of Cursednesse
He semyd freendly to hem that knewe him nought
But he was feendly bothe in werk and thouȝt
It wyrieth me to telle of his falsnesse
And natheles ȝet wol I it expresse
To that entent that men may be war therby
And for non other cause trewely
He putte this vnce of coper in to the Crosselette
And of the fuyr as swithe he hath it sette /
And kast in poudre and made the prest to blowe
And in his worching for to stoupe lowe
As he dide erst and al nas but a Iape
Right as him liste the prest he made his ape /
And afterward in to the Ingot he it caste
And in the panne putte it atte laste
Of water and in he put his owne hand
And in his sleeue as ȝe byforn hand
Herde me telle he hadde a siluer teyne
He slyly took it out this cursed heyne
Vnwetyng this prest of his false craft
And in the pannes botme he hath it laft
And in the water rombleth to and fro
And wonder pryuyly tok it vp also
The coper teyne nought knowyng this prest
And hidde it and hente him by the breest
And to him spak and thus sayde in his game
Stowpeth a doun by god ȝe ben to blame
Helpeth me now as I dide ȝou whiler
Put in ȝoure hand and loketh what is ther
This prest tok vp this siluer teyne anon
And thanne seyde the chanoun let vs gon
With thise thre teynes whiche that we haue wrought
To som goldsmith and wite if it be ought
For by my faith I nolde for myn hood
But if thei were siluer fyn and good
And that as swithe proued schal it be
Vnto the goldsmith with thise teynes thre
They wente and putte thise teynes in assay
To fyr and hamer might no man say nay
But they were as hem ouȝte for to be
This sottide prest who was gladder than he
Was neuer bryd gladder aȝeins the day
Ne nightyngale in the sesoun of May
Was neuere non that liste better to synge
Ne lady lustiere in Carolynge
And for to speke of loue and wommanhede
Ne knight in armes don an hardy dede
To stonden in grace of his lady deere
Than hadde this prest this craft for to lere
And to the chanoun thus he spak and sayde
For the loue of god that for vs all deyde /
And as I may deserue it vnto ȝow
What schal this receyt coste telleth now
By oure lady quod the chanoun it is deere
I warne ȝou for saue I and a frere /
In Engelond ther can no man it make
No fors quod he now sire for goddes sake
What schal I paye tel me I ȝou pray
I wys quod he it is ful deere I say
Sire at oo word if that the list it haue
Ȝe schulle paye fourty pound so god me saue
And ne were the frendschipe that ȝe dide er this
To me ȝe scholde paye more y wys
This prest the somme of fourty pound anon .
Of nobles fette and took hem euerychon
To this chanoun for this ilke receyt
Al his worchinge was fraude and deceyt
Sire prest he seyde I kepe for to haue no loos
Of my craft for I wolde it were kept cloos
And as ȝe loueth me kepeth it secre
For and men knewen al my subtilte
By god men wolde haue so gret envye
To me by cause of my philosophie
I scholde be deed there were non other weye
God it forbede quod the preest what seye
Ȝet hadde I leuer spenden al the good
Which that I haue and elles waxe I wood
Than that ȝe schulde falle in such mescheef
For ȝoure good wil sire haue ȝe right good preef
Quoth the chanoun and sire wol graunt mercy
He wente his wey and neuer the prest he sey
After that day and whan that this prest scholde
maken assay at swich tyme as he wolde
Of this receyt far wel it wolde not be
Lo thus byiaped and bygyled was he
Thus maketh he his introduccioun
To bringe folk to here destruccioun
Considereth sires how that in eche astate
Bitwixe men and gold ther is debate
So ferforth that vnnethes ther is non
This multiplyȝing blendeth so many oon
That in good faith I trowe that it be
The cause grettest of this skarsete
As men recorde many mo than I
This philosophres speken so mystily
In this craft that men can not come therby
In this craft that men hau now a daies
For ony witte that men han now a dayes
They may wel chitre and Iangle as don this Iayes
And in here termes sette lust and peyne
But to here purpos schul they neuer atteyne
A man may lightliche lerne if he hath ought
To multiplye and brynge his good to nouȝt
Lo such a lucre is in this lusty game
A mannes merthe it wol torne all to game
And empte also grete and heuye purses
And make folk to purchacen curses
Of hem that han therto here good y lent
O fy for schame they that haue be brent
Allas can they nat fle the fyres hete
Ȝe that it vsen I rede ȝe it lete
Lest ȝe lese al for bet than neuer is late
Neuer to thriue were to longe a date
Though ȝe prolle ay ȝe schull it neuer fynde
Ȝe ben as bolde as is bayard the blynde
That blundreth forth and peril casteth he non
He is as bold to renne agayn a stoon
As for to go bysydes in the weye
So fare ȝe that multiplie I seye
If that ȝoure yȝen may not seen aright
Loketh that ȝoure mynd lakke nought his sight
For though ȝe loke neuer so brode and stare /
Ȝe schulle nat wynne a myte in that chaffare
But wasten al that ȝe may Rappe and renne
Withdrawe the fir lest it so faste brenne
Medleth nomore with that art I mene
For if ȝe doon ȝour thrift is gon ful clene /
And right as swithe I wol ȝou telle heere
What that the philosophres sein in this matere /
Lo thus seith arnold of the newe toun
As his Rosarie maketh mencioun
He seith right thus withouten eny lye
Ther may no man mercurie mortifie
But if it be with his brotheres knowleching
How that he which that first seyde this thing /
Of Philosophres fader was hermes /
He saith how that the dragoun douteles
Ne dyeth not but if he be slayn
With his brother and that is for to sayn
By the dragoun mercurie and non other
He vnderstood and bremston were his brother
That on of Sol and luna were y drawe
And therfore sayde he tak heed to my sawe
Lat no man busye him this art for to seche
But he that the entencioun and the speche
Of philosophres vnderstonde can
And if he do he is a lewed man
For this science and this connyng quod he /
Is of the secre of Secrees parde
Also ther was a disciple of Plato
That on a tyme sayde his mayster to
As his book Somer wil bere witnesse
And this was his demaunde in sothfastnesse
Telle me the name of the pryuy stoon
And plato answerde vnto him anon
Tak the stoon that titanos men name
Which is that quod he magnasia the same /
Seyde Plato ȝee Sire and is it thus
This is ignotum per ignocius
What is magnasia goode sire I pray /
It is a water that is maad I say
Of elementes foure quod Plato
Tel me the roche goode sire quod he tho
Of that water if it be ȝour wille
Nay nay quod Plato certeyn that I nylle
The Philosophres were sworn echon
That they scholde discouere it to no mon
Ne in no book it write in no manere
For vnto crist it is so leef and deere
That he wil nat that it discouered be
But where it liketh to his deite
Man to enspire and eek for to defende
Whom that him liketh lo this is the ende
Thanne conclude I thus sithens that god of heuene
Ne wole nat that the Philosophres neuene
How that a man schal come vnto this stoon
I rede as for the beste lat it goon
For who so maketh god his aduersarie
As for to worche eny thing in contrarie /
Vnto his wille certes neuer schal he thriue
Though that he multiplie terme of his lyue
And there a poynt for ended is my tale /
God sende euery trewe man boote of his bale amen
¶ Heere is ended the Chanouns Yemannes tale ~
Here endeth the Chanons yomans tale / And next biginneth ⁊lb: the Prolog of þe doctor of phisik / ~
¶ Explicit ⁊lb: ¶ Here begynneth þe prologe of þe doctour of phisik
Whan this yoman his tale ended hadde
Of this fals Chanoun which was so badde
Oure oost gan sey treuly and certaine
This prest was begiled sothli to sayne
He wenyng for to be a philosophre
Til he right no gold left in his cofre
And sothli this prest had a litull Iape
This cursed Chanon put in his hode an Ape
But al this passe I ouer as nowe
Sir doctor of phisik I pray you
Tell vs a tale of som honest mater
Hit shal be don if the wol it her
Seid this doctoure / and his tale began anon
Now goode men / quod he herkeneth euerichon
Here endeth þe prolog of þe doctor of phisik / And next ⁊lb: biginneth the tale of the doctor of phisik /
Incipit prolog9 Magrim Phisici.
NOwe trewly qd oure Oste þis is a prati tale
For litel merveile it is þat þou lokest so pale
Seþen þou hast medeled wiþ so mony þinges
Wiþ bloweinge att þe cole to melte boþe brochez ⁊ ringes
And ope many Iewels dar .I. vnder take
And þat þi lorde couþe vs tel ; if we myht him ouere take
Bot lat him go adeuelwaye þe compaigny is neuer þe wers
And al suche fals harlotes .I. sette not be hem a kers
Bot latt þas ouere nowe al þes subtilitees
And sume worþi man tel vs sunme veritees
As ȝe worschipful Maister of Phisike
Telleþ vs somme tale þat is a cronyke
Þat we may of ȝowe leren sum witte
Qd þe Maister of Phisik a tale þat .I. finde writte
In cronyke passed of olde tyme
Herkeneþ for .I. wil tel it ȝow in rime

¶ The Prologe / of the Persons tale
⁊ Incipit prologus Rectoris fabule
By that the Maunciple hadde his tale al ended
The Sonne // fro the South lyne is descended
So lowe / that he nas nat to my sighte
Degrees . 29 . as of highte
Ten of the Clokke / it was so as I gesse
For eleuene foot and litel moore / or lesse
My shadwe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of swiche feet / as my lengthe parted weere
In . 6 . feet equal / of proporcioun
Ther with / the Mones exaltacioun
I mene Libra / alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a Thropes ende
For which oure hoost as he was wont to gye
As in this cas / oure Ioly compaignye
Seyde in this wise / lordynges euerichon
Oure lord seid lordyng euerychone
Now lakketh vs / no tales / mo than oon
Fulfild is my Sentence / and my decree
I trowe / that we han herd of ech degree
Who wile now telle a tale let se
At that forsoith it lekith mee
Almoost fulfild is al myn ordinaunce
I pray to god / so yeue hym right good chaunce
That telleth this tale / to vs lustily
Sire preest quod he / artow a Vicary
Or arte a parson / sey sooth by thy fey
Be what thow be / ne breke thow nat oure pley
For euery man saue thow / hath toold his tale
Vnbokele / and shewe vs / what is in thy Male
For trewely / me thynketh by thy cheere
Thow sholdest / knette vp wel a greet matere
Telle vs a fable anon / for Cokkes bones
This parson / answerde al atones
Thow getest fable noon / ytoold for me
For Poul / that writeth vnto Thymothe
Repreueth hem / that weyuen Soothfastnesse
And tellen fables / and swich wrecchednesse
Why sholde I sowen draf out of my fest
Whan I may sowen whete / if that me lest
For which I seye / that if yow list to heere
Moralitee / and vertuous matere
And thanne / that ye wol yeue me Audience
I wole ful fayn / at Cristes reuerence
Do all the besynesse that euer I can
To telle some morall thung to plese god and man
Do yow plesance / leueful / as I kan
But trusteth wel / I am a Southren man
I kan nat geste / rom / ram / ruf / by lettre
Ne god woot rym holde I but litel bettre
And therfore if yow lest I wol nat glose
I wol yow telle / a myrie tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste / and make an ende
And Ihu for his grace / wit me sende
To shewe yow the wey / in this viage
Of thilke parfit glorious pilgrymage
That highte Ierusalem celestial
And if ye vouche sauf anon I shal
Bigynne vpon my tale / for which I preye
Telle youre auys / I kan no bettre seye
But nathelees / this meditacioun
I putte it ay / vnder correccioun
Of clerkes / for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence / trusteth wel
Therfore / I make protestacioun
That I wol stonde / to correccioun
Vpon this word / we han assented soone
For as it semed / it was for to doone
To enden / in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym / space and audience
And bede oure hoost he sholde to hym seye
That alle we / to telle his tale hym preye
Oure hoost hadde the wordes for vs alle
Sire preest quod he / now faire yow bifalle
Sey what yow list and we wol gladly heere
And with that word / he seyde in this manere
Telleth quod he / youre meditacioun
But hasteth yow / the sonne wole adoun
Beth fructuous / and that in litel space
And to do wel / god sende yow his grace

Heer eendith the persous prolog
and begynneth his tale

div.ab: Here bigynneth the Persons tale

Iere 6o State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne
that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

right so the synful man that loueth his synne
hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng

but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence

Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth
hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde
iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche
ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he
sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule

thanne
is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth
in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to
do penance and neuere moore to do synne

and this sorwe shal ben
in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte

first for man hath
agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt
for he hath agilt his fader celestial

and yet moore sharpe and
poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym
that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle

The causes that oghten moeuen a man to Contricioun been vj
ffirst a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes

but looke
that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret
shame and sorwe for his gilt for Iob seith Synful men doon
werkes worthy of Confessioun

And therfore seith Ezechie I
wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn
herte

And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye
were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god

but
for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of
the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and
foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle

And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte
tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng

and
yet be ye fouler for youre longe contynuynge in synne and
youre synful vsage for which ye been roten in youre synne
as a beest in his donge

swiche manere of thoughtes maken
a man haue shame of his synne and no delit as god seyth
by the prophete Ezechiel

ye shal remembre yow of youre
weyes and they shullen displese yow soothly synnes been
the weyes that leden folk to helle

The seconde cause that oghte
make a man to han desdeyn of synne is this that as seith
Seint Peter who so that dooth synne is thral of synne and
synne put a man in greet thraldam

And therfore seith the
prophete Ezechiel I wente sorweful in desdayn of my self
Certes wel oghte a man haue desdayn of synne and with
drawe hym fro that thraldom and vileynye

And lo what
seith Seneca in this matere he seith thus though I wiste
that god neither god ne man ne sholde neuere kNowe it yet
wolde Ihaue desdayn for to do synne

And the same Seneca also
seith Iam born to gretter thynges than to be thral to my body or than for to maken of my body a thral

ne a fouler thral
may no man ne womman make of his body than for to yeue his
body to synne

al were it the fouleste cherl or the fouleste womman
that lyueth and leest of value yet is he thanne moore foul and
moore in seruitute

euere fro the hyer degree that man falleth the
moore is he thral and moore to god and to the world vil and abhomynable

O goode god wel oghte man haue greet desdayn
of synne sith that thurgh synne ther he was fre Now is he
maked bonde

And ther fore seith Seint Augustyn If thow
hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne haue thow
thanne desdayn that thow thy self sholdest do synne

take
reward of thy value that thow ne be to foul to thy self

Allas wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn to ben seruantz
and thralles to synne and soore ben ashamed of hem self

that god
of his endelees goodnesse hath set hem in heigh estat or yeuen hem wit strengthe of body heele beautee prosperitee

and boghte hem fro the deeth with his herte blood that they so
vnkyndely agayns his gentilesse quyten hym so vileynsly
to slawghtre of hir owene soules

O goode god ye wommen that been of so greet beautee remembreth yow of the
prouerbe of Salomon he seith

likneth a fair womman that is
a fool of hire body lyk to a ryng of gold that were in the
groyn of a Sowe

for right as a Sowe wroteth in euerich
ordure so wroteth she hire beaute in stynkynge ordure of
synne

The thridde cause that oughte moeue a man to
Contricion is drede of the day of dome and of the horrible peynes of helle

For as Seint Ierome seith At euery
